loans.name: Laweng

texts.en:
Laweng  is in the business of brewing and selling of local alcohol beverages and is requesting a loan to purchase more brewing materials for distillation .  Laweng is 40 years old and is married. Her husband is a security guard. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more brewing materials for distillation

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 35-year-old single mother of two children, ages twelve and three years old. Her twelve-year-old is attending school. She is a farmer in the Murang'a area of the Central Province of Kenya. She's been a farmer for twelve years and sells milk, eggs, bananas, 'sukuma wiki' (kale), and grains. The main challenge in her business is insufficient acreage to plant more fodder (animal feed). She must lease a farm and employ laborers for the cows. She says that sources of capital to undertake more projects are limited.

She successfully completed two previous loans through Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan for Kes 40,000 to purchase a chaff cutter, which is a device for cutting feed for cattle. In the future, she would like to have a bigger poultry project with over 2,000 layers and at least one good cow producing forty litres a day. She says that she hopes to continue to be a Juhudi client, and that she will be able to save money for her family now because the chaff cutter will reduce waste and the cost of feed.

About Juhudi Kilimo

Juhudi Kilimo is a for-profit social enterprise focused on the economic development of Kenya. It has a unique approach to financing agribusiness value chains, from production of raw products to processing and delivery of goods: by providing asset financing and technical assistance funding to smallholder farmers and rural enterprises. This approach to poverty alleviation supports sustainable wealth creation in rural communities, establishes local engines of income generation, and generates employment, economic growth and dynamism as well as demand for inputs.

loans.use: To buy a chaff cutter to cut fodder

loans.name: Hamida's Group

texts.en:
Hamida is 48 years of age and married with six children between the ages of 18 and 30 years. Three of her children go to school. She lives in a rented two-roomed house, where she stays.with eight people. She has three meals a day. She takes care of additional family members. Her three greatest expenses in a month are paying electricity bills, school fees for children and rent for her residence and business premises. 

Hamida has a stall in Ndeeba selling raw and roasted maize and, besides this maize business, she also sells bananas in her stall. She mainly sells on a retail basis. She works seven days a week. She serves about 30 customers a day. She has done this business for six years now. Her main challenges are that there are many stalls that sell maize and bananas and the seasonality. She has been with MCDT, a Kiva partner, for eight years, servicing her 16th loan and working along with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of raw maize and bunches of bananas.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of maize and bunches of bananas

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is 70 years old with eight adult children. She is a dairy farmer in the Murang'a area of the Central Province of Kenya. She also earns income from coffee and milk sales and maize and bean farming. She's been a farmer for over twenty years and also keeps bees and rabbits. She says that the major challenges for her business are lack of funds to buy more dairy cows and feed for her rabbits.

She requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow. In the future, she hopes to have at least a total of four dairy cows, increase her bee hives, and acquire more rabbits. She hopes to increase her income through milk sales so that she won't have to rely on her children. She says that the future is bright because Juhudi loans will help her and other members achieve their farming goals.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 77 years old and has seven adult children. She is a farmer near Murang'a, in the Central Province of Kenya, and before she became a farmer she sold clothing. She's now been a farmer for over twenty years and earns her income selling milk and eggs. She says that the main challenges to her business are low prices for her eggs and milk and having only a small amount of acreage for planting fodder (animal feed).

She successfully completed a previous loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes 25,000 and requested this new loan for Kes 30,000 to purchase a a dairy goat and poultry. In the future, she'd like to have more income to be able to sustain herself and other members of her family who have problems. She hopes that, God willing, she will be able to acquire more loans.

About Juhudi Kilimo

Juhudi Kilimo is a for-profit social enterprise focused on the economic development of Kenya. It has a unique approach to financing agribusiness value chains, from production of raw products to processing and delivery of goods: by providing asset financing and technical assistance funding to smallholder farmers and rural enterprises. This approach to poverty alleviation supports sustainable wealth creation in rural communities, establishes local engines of income generation, and generates employment, economic growth and dynamism as well as demand for inputs.

loans.use: To buy a dairy goat and poultry

loans.name: Alayo

texts.en:
Alayo F. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and beans and is requesting a loan to stock onions, tomatoes and cassava to sell. Alayo is 30 years old and married to a driver. She has a child who goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC, a Kiva partner, has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock onions, tomatoes and cassava to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en: Christopher is a 33-year-old married man with three daughters and one son, all of whom attend school. Through his business, Brotherwood Furniture, he has been selling beds, tables and sofa sets for eight years. With the 15,000 Kenyan shillings loan, Christopher wants to buy timber and paints. He hopes to someday open more branches and own a house and a car.

loans.use: To purchase timber and paints

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta is 30 years old and married, with a four-year-old child, who is already attending school. She is a dairy farmer in the Murang'a area of the Central Province of Kenya and has been farming for three years. She says that the main challenges to her business are the cost of veterinary services now and then and having only a small amount of acreage on which to plant fodder (animal feed). 

She successfully completed a previous loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes 30,000 and has requested this loan to purchase dairy goats. Her family will use the goat milk for consumption so that all the cow's milk can be sold for a better overall income. In the future, she would like to have at least two cows and three dairy goats. She says that Juhudi has helped her acquire her first asset, which calved to a heifer, and that she is very grateful.

About Juhudi Kilimo

Juhudi Kilimo is a for-profit social enterprise focused on the economic development of Kenya. It has a unique approach to financing agribusiness value chains, from production of raw products to processing and delivery of goods: by providing asset financing and technical assistance funding to smallholder farmers and rural enterprises. This approach to poverty alleviation supports sustainable wealth creation in rural communities, establishes local engines of income generation, and generates employment, economic growth and dynamism as well as demand for inputs.

loans.use: To buy dairy goats.

loans.name: United Women Group

texts.en: Korto K.'s business is the sale of rubber materials and food such as seasonings, oils, pepper, etc. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail from a table in the Red Light Market. She has been running this business for more than 25 years and hopes to own a shop in the near future. She is 40 years old and is engaged to be married. Korto has 5 children: the youngest is age 1 year, 7 months and the oldest is 28 years old. Most of her children are in school from 5th grade to freshman university. She also cares for two nephews. Korto started by selling oranges and her working capital when she started was 150.00 Liberian dollars. She speaks well to her customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Korto needs this loan to purchase more seasonings, salt, rice, etc., to improve her business. She dreams of giving her children a good education in order for them to have a good future. Korto and her family live and work in and around the FDA junction community near the Red Light Market, which is near Monrovia and is the biggest market in Liberia. Korto herself was only able to finish 5th grade due to poverty. Korto is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "United Women". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Korto is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more seasonings, salt, rice, etc.

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is 55 years of age and widowed with six children between the ages of 14 and 28. Three of her children go to school. She lives in a rented two-roomed house, where she stays.with four people. She has three meals a day. She takes care of additional family members. Her three greatest expenses in a month are paying utility bills, school fees for her children and rent for her residence and business premises. 

Winnie has  a retail shop in Mulago near Mulago hospital and sells all categories of merchandise, ranging from children’s clothing to sugar, soap, salt and roasted maize. Besides this retail business, she is also nurse in the Mulago hospital. She mainly sells on a retail basis. She works seven days a week. She serves about 30 customers a day. She has done this business for six years now. Her main challenges are that there are many retail shops selling the same merchandise and seasonality. She has been with MCDT for 13 years, servicing her 24th loan and working with the same group mates for four years. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise, like bags of sugar, cartons of salt and boxes of soap. She is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to start selling on a wholesale basis only.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise like soap, salt and bags of sugar

loans.name: God's Goodness Group

texts.en: Rachel S. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God’s Goodness. She is 54 years old and married with five children, aged 18 to 30 with educational levels ranging from 8th grade to university. Rachel and her family live and work in the Pipeline Road Community in Paynesville near Liberia's capital, Monrovia. Rachel herself could not continue past 6th grade in school due to poverty. Rachel’s business is the sale of vegetables. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail from a table to residents of the Pipeline Paynesville community. She has been running this business for more than four years and hopes to own a shop in the near future. Rachel started selling with a very low amount of capital and now faces difficulty with funding her business -- the money she has is too small to grow her business well. Rachel says she sells good products in order to encourage her customers to continue buying from her. Rachel needs this loan to purchase more vegetables for resale and as working capital for her business. She dreams of being able to improve her family's living conditions. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Rachel is the one holding the sign. Joe W. is in the inset photo in the lower right corner. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables for resale

loans.name: Phocas

texts.en:
Phocas was born in 1982 and he is single; he lives with his parents in the Kigali province, Gasabo district, Remera sector, in the region called Nyabisindu where he has his business selling different kinds of products such as toothpaste, juice, cosmetic products, biscuits, and so on. This is his third successful year and his shop is open from 8 AM until late in the evening hours.

Phocas has chosen this business because it is appropriate in this region despite of the insufficiency of investment funds he is facing. For this reason, he is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, he will purchase additional goods which are highly demanded and he hopes that they will help him to earn more profits. With these profits, he will be able to sort out some problems as well as building a secure future for himself.

loans.use: additional products for resale

loans.name: A. Victoire

texts.fr: N. A.Victoire est née le 12 Janvier 1976 et est mariée à ADJOVI Agapit. Le couple a deux enfants à charge, dont un représente leur propre enfant et est scolarisé. Il y a un an de cela que la famille s'est installée au quartier Agla à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est surtout le mari de Victoire qui assure les charges de la famille, mais Victoire vient souvent en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Victoire a fréquenté jusqu'à l'université. Mais depuis 4 ans environs, Victoire vend des tissus et des chaussures au quartier Sainte Rita à Cotonou. Parallèlement à cette activité, Victoire a une buvette où elle reçoit ses clients venant payer des boissons. Victoire s'approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Très sollicitée par ses clients, Victoire ambitionne renforcer son capital et agrandir son étalalge afin de faire face à la demande sans cesse croissante de la clientèle. C'est ce qui a conduit Victoire à solliciter un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A.Victoire N. was born on 12 January 1976 and is married to Agapit ADJOVI. The couple has two children to support, one of which is their own child and is at school. A year ago the family settled down in the Agla district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Victoire's husband assumes the bulk of the household expenses, but Victoire often helps him with these, thanks to the income which she gets from her activity. Victoire went to school up to university level. But for around four years now she has been selling fabric and shoes in the Sainte Rita district of Cotonou. At the same time she has a refreshment stall where she welcomes her customers who come to pay for their drinks. Victoire gets her supplies in Lomé in Togo, one of Bénin's neigboring countries, and also in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. In great demand from her customers, Victoire's ambition is to strengthen her capital and expand her display in order to meet the ever incoreasing demand of her customers. This has led her to apply for her first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of fabric and shoes

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en: Jenifer is a 37-year-old married woman. She has been running her beauty salon, where she offers services and sells hair products, for two years. Previously she worked as a clerk for a private company. With this 40,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to boost her business by purchasing stock. She hopes to open a chain of salons in the future. Jenifer describes herself as very hardworking.

loans.use: To increase stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of spare parts

loans.name: Maura Estela

texts.es:
En el municipio de Chichigalpa, la señora Maura H. es propietaria de su propio negocio de servicio de fotocopias donde le visitan muchas personas y muchos estudiantes para sacar fotocopia a diferentes documentos y ella muy atentamente los atiende con su único objetivo de que se sientan satisfechos con el servicio que ella brinda.
Actualmente ha solicitado un crédito para ser invertido en la compra de papelería para llevar a cabo la actividad y así cuando los clientes lleguen, ella pueda tener suficiente papel para realizar las fotocopias.
texts.en:
Maura H. owns her photocopying service in Chichigalpa. Many customers and students visit her shop to make copies of various documents. Her only objective is that they leave satisfied with the service she provides so she, herself, graciously takes care of them. She is asking for funding to buy paper so that she will have enough on hand to make all the photocopies her customers ask for.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy photocopier paper.

loans.name: Silvia Gabriela

texts.es:
En el municipio de Chichigalpa en Chinandega, la señora Silvia O. se dedica a atender su pulpería donde vende todo tipo de productos comestibles tales como galletas, meneítos, golosinas y otros comestibles. También ella vende piezas de ropa para niños que exhibe en una vitrina.
Ella es madre de dos hijos a los que debe de brindarle las condiciones necesarias para que estudien. Solicita el crédito para invertirlo en la compra de los productos tales como arroz, frijoles, azúcar, aceite, enlatados, leche, lácteos para ofrecerlos en la pulpería y así continuar mejorando sus condiciones del negocio y beneficiar a su amada familia.
texts.en:
In the municipality of Chichigalpa, in Chinandega, Silvia O. works in her general store, where she sells all sorts of edible products such as cookies, cheese puffs, candy and other foods. She also sells clothing, which she exhibits in a showcase. She is the mother of two children, and she needs to provide them with everything necessary so that they can continue in school. She is requesting a loan so that she can invest it in buying products such as rice, beans, cooking oil, canned foods, and milk and other dairy products for her store. This will allow her to continue improving her living conditions and providing benefits to her beloved family.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing products for her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Valantino Nassiwa‘S Group

texts.en:
Valantina has a stall in Owino Market (one of the busiest markets in Uganda) selling fruits and vegetables. She sells all kinds of fruit including mangoes, pawpaws, oranges and yellow bananas. She mainly sells retail. She works seven days a week and serves about 30 customers a day. She has been in this business for two years now. Her main challenge is that there are many stalls selling fruit so the competition is very high. 

Valantina is 40 years of age and married with three children between the ages of 5 and 15. All her children go to school. She lives in a rented two-room house with six people. She has three meals a day. She takes care of additional family members. Her three largest monthly expenses are utility bills, school fees for her children, and rent for her  residence and business premises. 

Valantina has been with MCDT for two years – now on her fifth loan with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more baskets of fruits and vegetables. She hopes to see her business grow and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Oke Yabo

texts.fr: V. Oke Yabo s'est installée il y a un an au quartier Agla à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  C'est un célibataire sans enfant qui vit et supporte seule ses charges. Oke Yabo n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses différents besoins, Oke Yabo vend depuis près de 16 ans, des produits de quincaillerie, une activité qu'elle mène passionnément et qui lui procure de revenu. Oke Yabo s'approvisionne au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Par contre, Oke Yabo vend ses produits dans sa boutique size au quartier Sainte Rita à Cotonou. C'est la première fois que Oke Yabo  sollicite un prêt auprès de ALIDé. Ce prêt lui servira à renforcer son activité et mieux faire face aux besoins de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
A year ago, Oke Yabo V. moved into the Agla district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. She is a single woman without any children and lives alone, assuming responsibility for her own expenses. Oke Yabo has not been to school. In order to meet her different needs, she has, for almost 16 years, been selling hardware products, a business which she runs with passion and which brings her in an income. Oke Yabo gets her supplies in Nigeria, a neighboring country of Bénin, and also at Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. However, she sells her products in her shop which is in the Sainte Rita district of Cotonou. This is the first time that Oke Yabo has applied for a loan from ALIDé. The loan will be used to build up her business and to meet the needs of her customers more readily.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of paints and sheet metal

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en: Sandra B. is a 49-year-old married woman who lives in Prk Patinio, Brgy Bocana, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by fishing, retailing water and fattening pigs. Sandra’s husband, Jerry, works as a fisherman and they have three children between the ages of 13 and 19. All of the children currently go to school and they also help their parents with the business as part of their daily chores. Sandra joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1995 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family's income with her pig fattening, fishing and water retailing businesses. Now she earns an average monthly income of 33,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) from her business activities. Sandra is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP was used to fund the operation of her businesses and it had a positive impact on the businesses and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 12th loan of 19,500 PHP which she intends to use on her pig fattening, fishing and water retailing businesses. Sandra is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of fish for resale

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en:
Pilar G. is a 51-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy Talakdan, Cuayan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living operating a repair shop and buying and selling rice. Pilar’s husband helps her run the business and they have nine grown up children. Some of them have their own families, while the others work to help cover the household needs.

Pilar joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family's income with her repair shop and from buying and selling rice. Now she earns an average monthly income of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from her business activities.

Pilar is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP was used to fund the operations of her repair shop and rice business, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is requesting her 13th loan, in the amount of 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use on her repair shop and to buy more rice to resell. Pilar is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem  that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of vegetables

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.fr: Née en 1958, K. Dorcas est mariée à ZOHOUN Ernest et est mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit depuis 10 ans environs, au quartier Fifadji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Dorcas n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Après son échec, et pour se prendre en charge, Dorcas a commencé depuis près de 10 ans, à vendre de la bouillie de maïs, accompagné de pâté (fait à base de la farine de blé et d'huile végétale) à Fifadji. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Dorcas achète ses produits. Dorcas est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu cinq crédits auprès de l'institution. Tous les cinq crédits ont été bien remboursés. La clientèle de Dorcas s'accroît au jour le jour ; mais Dorcas n'arrive plus à la satisfaire vu le peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose. C'est la raison pour laquelle Dorcas sollicite un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui lui servira à renforcer son activité pour mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1958, Ms. K. Dorcas is married to Mr. ZOHOUN Ernest and is the mother of six children.  The family has lived for about ten years in the Fifadji district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Together, the couple ensures that family responsibilities are met.  Dorcas attended primary school only.  Following her failure, in order to support herself, she started selling corn porridge ten years ago in Fifadji. The porridge is served with pâté (made from wheat flour and vegetable oil).  Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she purchases her supplies.  She is a previous ALIDé client having already obtained five loans from this micro-finance institution.  All five loans have been repaid.  Her customer base is growing day by day;  but she is no longer able to satisfy her customers, since she has few financial means at her disposal.  For these reasons, Dorcas is requesting a sixth loan from ALIDé to be used for bolstering her business, so as to satisfy her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying corn, wheat flour, and vegetable oil

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en: Roberto G. is a 42-year old married man who lives in Barangay Maytubig, Isabela, Negros Occidental. He earns his living driving a passenger tricycle and selling chicken and pork barbecue as well as Ready-To-Wear (RTW) clothes. Roberto’s wife, Christina, helps in running the business. They have one child who is 2 months old. The couple is striving hard to provide their child with a good future. Roberto G. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 with the hope that he would be able to improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of his loans from NWTF-PD, he has been able to increase their family income by engaging in chicken/pork barbecue sales, driving a passenger tricycle and selling RTW. Now he earns an average monthly income of 10,000 Philippine pesos from his business activities. Roberto is a member in good standing. His previous loan of Php 18,000 was used to maintain his tricycle and to add capital to his chicken/pork barbecue and RTW businesses, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now he is borrowing, for his seventh loan, the amount of Php 19,000, which he intends to use for tricycle maintenance and the chicken/pork barbecue and RTW businesses. Roberto is working hard to achieve his dreams and aspirations for his family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Maintenance for his motorcycle and additional working capital for his other businesses

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith Duenas is a 53-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy Maytubig, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store and by pig fattening.

Judith’s husband, Renato, helps run the businesses. They have five children who are between 15 and 31 years of age. One of her children is currently going to school and helps in the business. Judith joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,400 from her business activities.

Judith is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 was used to fund operations of her general store and pig fattening businesses, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 17th loan in the amount of PHP 18,000, which she intends to use in her general store and pig fattening business.  Judith is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Grace Kobugabe ‘S Group

texts.en: Grace is 30 years of age and married with two children aged 5 and 10 years. Both her children go to school. She lives in a rented one-room house where she stays with four people. She has three meals a day. She takes care of additional family members. Her three greatest expenses in a month are utility bills, school fees for her children and rent for her residence and business premises. Grace has a stall in Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, selling second hand clothes. She mainly sells on a retail basis. She works seven days a week. She serves about 30 customers a day. She has done this business for two years. Her main challenges are that there are many stalls selling second hand clothes, there are few customers coming to them, the increasing prices of second hand clothes and the very high competition.  She has been with MCDT for two years servicing her fifth loan, working all the time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start selling on wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying alcoholic beverages

loans.name: Sandra

texts.es:
Sandra J. B. es una señora de 39 años de edad, la  cual vive  con sus tres hijos, en una comunidad llamada El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba, Provincia de Cartago.  Es una pequeña comunidad rural de aproximadamente dos mil habitantes. Sus pobladores se dedican a la producción de leche y siembra de café. Tiene un relieve irregular y mucho del terreno se mantiene como bosque tropical húmedo. La comunidad tiene paisajes muy pintorescos que combinan el bosque tropical con dos lindas lagunas, plantaciones de café y lecherías. El Sauce se localiza aproximadamente a hora y media en bus de Turrialba, el centro de comercio más cercano. Sin embargo, varias veces al año el camino se vuelve intransitable por las lluvias que azotan la zona. Este es sin duda uno de los principales desafíos para la comunidad. 

Cuando no existían actividades muchas personas optaron por salir a buscar trabajos en Turrialba o en fincas bananeras ubicadas en la Zona Atlántica de Costa Rica. Actualmente los precios del café y la leche han mejorado, por lo tanto los vecinos buscan cómo invertir en proyectos en la misma zona y de esta forma evitar migrar.

Doña Sandra se dedica a la producción de leche como una forma de generar ingresos para su familia. Dice estar muy contenta porque gracias a este proyecto ha podido salir adelante. 

Doña Sandra desea obtener un micro crédito por un monto de ¢500.000 (quinientos mil colones) para comprar  una vaca lechera más y así aumentar la producción de leche ya que desea ser una microempresaria exitosa y  así poder ayudar a que su familia siga adelante esto es una de las cosas que la motiva a esforzarse y trabajar con mucho esmero. 

Doña Sandra es socia de la Asociación de Productores de El Sauce, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico. También destaca que gracias a este tipo de organizaciones y medios facilitadores de crédito puede dedicar más tiempo a las actividades productivas.
texts.en:
Sandra J. B. is a 39-year-old woman, who lives with her three children in the community of El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba, in the province of Cartago. This is a small, rural community with a population of approximately two thousand. The people from the community produce milk and grow coffee. Her land is irregular and much of it is a tropical rainforest. The community has very picturesque scenery, which combines the tropical rainforest with two beautiful lagoons, coffee plantations and dairy farms. El Sauce is located about an hour and a half on a bus from Turrialba, which is the closest commercial center. Nonetheless, many times in the year the road becomes impassable because of the rains in the area. This is, without a doubt, one of the main challenges for the community. When there weren’t job opportunities available, many people decided to leave to find jobs in Turrialba or on banana plantations in the Atlántica area of Costa Rica. At present, the prices of coffee and milk have improved, and, for the most part, her neighbors are looking to invest in projects in their own area and avoid migrating. Ms. Sandra produces milk to earn income for her family. She says that this makes her very happy because she has been able to go forward. Ms. Sandra wants a small microloan of 500,000 CRC to buy a milk cow and, in this way, to increase the production to milk, since she wants to be a successful micro-entrepreneur. This will also help her family to continue moving forward, whichis one of her motives for working hard and carefully. Ms. Sandra is a member of the Asociación de Productores de El Sauce, one of the 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her first loan, and with it, she hopes to continue growing on both a personal and financial level. She is also very thankful for these organizations, which facilitate access to credit so that she can spend more time pursuing productive activities.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a milk cow

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen R. P. es una señora de 39 años de edad quien vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos en una comunidad llamada El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba, Provincia de Cartago.  Es una pequeña comunidad rural de aproximadamente dos mil habitantes. Sus pobladores se dedican a la producción de leche y siembra de café. Tiene un relieve irregular y mucho del terreno se mantiene como bosque tropical húmedo. La comunidad tiene paisajes muy pintorescos que combinan el bosque tropical con dos lindas lagunas, plantaciones de café y lecherías. El Sauce se localiza aproximadamente a hora y media en bus de Turrialba, el centro de comercio más cercano. Sin embargo, varias veces al año el camino se vuelve intransitable por las lluvias que azotan la zona. Este es sin duda uno de los principales desafíos para la comunidad. 

Cuando no existían actividades muchas personas optaron por salir a buscar trabajos en Turrialba o en fincas bananeras ubicadas en la Zona Atlántica de Costa Rica. Actualmente los precios del café y la leche han mejorado, por lo tanto los vecinos buscan cómo invertir en proyectos en la misma zona y de esta forma evitar migrar.

Actualmente doña Carmen ordeña a en una pequeña instalación de madera que acondicionó como sala de ordeño. Dice que por día logra producir aproximadamente 30 litros de leche y con otra vaca su producción aumentará muchos más litros diarios por lo cual esta muy emocionada de poder ver como su negocio crece y se fortalece.
Doña Carmen desea obtener un microcrédito por ¢500.000(quinientos mil colones) para comprar otra vaca y así aumentar la producción de leche. Ella sabe que contar con otra  vaca es un mayor sacrificio y demandará más trabajo pero dice que si quiere sacar a su familia adelante tiene que esforzarse en producir más.

Doña Carmen es socia de la Asociación de Productores de El Sauce, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su octavo préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico. También destaca que gracias a este tipo de organizaciones y medios facilitadores de crédito puede dedicar más tiempo a las actividades productivas.
texts.en:
Carmen R. P., 39, lives with her husband and their three children in the El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba community in the Cartago province. It is a small, rural community with approximately 2,000 inhabitants. The inhabitants work at milk production and planting coffee. The landscape is irregular, and much of the land is humid tropical rain forest. The community has very picturesque scenery that combines tropical rain forest with two lovely lakes, coffee plantations, and dairy farms. El Sauce is approximately one and a half hours by bus from Turrialba, which is the closest commercial center. Several times a year, however, the road becomes impassable because of the rains that fall in the area. This is without a doubt one of the biggest challenges for the community. When there isn't any work, many people choose to look for jobs in Turrialba or on banana plantations located in the Atlantic region of Costa Rica. Currently the prices of coffee and milk have improved, so the local people are looking to invest in projects in their own areas so they don’t have to travel to find work. Carmen currently milks in a small wooden installation set up as the milking room. She says that she produces approximately 30 liters of milk a day. With another cow, her production will increase by many more liters daily. She is excited to be able to see how her business grows and becomes stronger. Carment wishes to get a micro loan for ¢500,000 (five hundred thousand colones) to buy another cow and increase her milk production. She knows that having another cow is a big sacrifice and will demand more work. But, she says that if she wants to get the family ahead she needs to put forth great effort to produce more. Carmen is a member of the Association of Producers in El Sauce, one of the 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her eighth loan, and she expects to continue growing on a personal level and economically. She also points out that thanks to this kind of organization that serve as a means of facilitating loans she can dedicate more time to productive activities.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Morgiane

texts.fr: Née le 17 Avril 1979, G. Morgiane est mariée à DANVIKPENON André et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit à Hêvié dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi au Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Morgiane n'a fait que l'école primaire. Depuis une dizaine d'année, Morgiane mène comme activité, la vente de maïs au marché de Gbégamey à Cotonou. Parallèlement à cette activité, Morgiane vend des fruits. Morgiane s'approvisionne à Parakou, dans le Nord du Bénin. L'activité de Morgiane lui génère de revenu qu'elle utilise pour la développer davantage et pour venir en aide à son mari en ce qui concerne les charges de la famille. Morgiane est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant bénéficié autrefois de trois crédits auprès de l'institution. Morgiane a bien remboursé les trois crédits. Malgré la passion qu'elle a pour son activité, Morgiane ne dispose pas d'assez de moyens pouvant lui permettre de renforcer davantage son activité et de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. Pour ce fait, Morgiane sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born on April 17, 1979, Ms. G. Morgiane is married to Mr. DANVIKPENON André and is the mother of two children, who are both in school.  The family lives in Hêvié, in the community of Abomey Calavi, in Benin.  Together, the couple ensures that family responsibilities are met. Morgiane attended primary school only.  For ten years, she has been running a business selling corn at the Gbégamey market in Cotonou.  Aside from this work, she sells fruit.  She stocks up in Parakou, in northern Benin.  Her business generates the revenues she uses to develop it further and to help out her husband where it concerns family expenses.  She is a previous ALIDé client having benefited in the past from three loans from this micro-finance institution.  She has repaid all three loans.  Despite the passion she has for her work, Morgiane doesn't have enough funds available to enable her to bolster her business further and to satisfy customer demands.  In order to do so, she's requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 100-kg sacks of corn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Wife's Cesarean section

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en:
T. Elmira is the leader of this group. She lives in a village with her family. Elmira is 51 years old. At this age, she has two sons and one daughter. One of her sons is married and Elmira has been very happy being able to raise two grandchildren.  Elmira’s husband has already reached retirement age and if he wished he could just stay at home and obtain retirement pension. However having worked all his life, Elmira’s husband has preferred to stay active and engage himself in some kind of job instead of staying at home and having rest. He is working as a stoker at a police station. So has Elmira. She works as a cleaner at the same police station. Elmira would like to make use of her free time and find herself an additional occupation after work. She has decided to get engaged in cattle breeding. Besides, she needs to pay for her daughter’s college education. Therefore Elmira has decided to apply for this loan. She plans to obtain it and purchase a foal for feeding and resale. One of Elmira’s plans is to save money together with her children and make a gift for her husband: buy him a car. 

Elmira’s partners are: 

E. U. Mirbek, 22, is married and has two children. His wife stays at home and takes care of the children. Mirbek works in a fish factory and breeds cattle as well. Mirbek needs a loan to buy five sheep for breeding. 

A. Jazgul, 25, is a mother of two children. Her husband works as a shepherd. Besides he has his own cattle and trades in cattle at the local cattle market. Jazgul has applied for this loan to purchase three sheep for resale. 

O. Ishengul, 49, is a mother of three children. Her husband is disabled. The children work and support their parents. Ishengul cannot work anywhere as she has to look after her husband. Therefore she wants to try cattle breeding. She hopes to obtain this loan and purchase some sheep for resale. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a foal for feeding and resale

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: A. Julienne réside depuis environs 40 ans au quartier Sainte Cécile à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Julienne est mariée à DJOTCHOU Nounangnon, un pêcheur, et est mère de six enfants. Seulement quatre des enfants restent encore à la charge du couple. Certains enfants sont scolarisés. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. N'ayant jamais été à l'école, pour assurer ses différentes charges, Julienne vend du poisson frit et de l'akassa (aliment local préparé à base d'amidon de maïs) dans son quartier à Sainte Cécile. De façon secondaire, Julienne vend également des crabes, ce qui lui permet d'avoir une autre source de revenu. Julienne s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de trois crédits auprès de l'institution, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. La clientèle de Julienne s'accroît au jour le jour ; mais Julienne n'arrive plus à satisfaire toute la demande, compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose. Julienne sollicite à cet effet, un quatrième crédit afin de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
A. Julienne has lived for about forty years in the Sainte Cécile neighborhood of Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. Julienne is married to DJOTCHOU Nounangnon, a fisherman, and is the mother of six children. Only four children are still supported by the couple. Some of the children are in school. The couple supports the family together. Never having been to school, in order to pay various expenses, Julienne sells fried fish and akassa (local food prepared from cornstarch) in her neighborhood in Sainte Cécile. Secondarily, Julienne also sells crabs, which allows her to have another source of income. Julienne gets her supplies in Dantokpa, international market of Benin. She is already an ALIDé client, having previously received three loans from the institution, loans which she has fully repaid. Julienne's clientele grows from day to day, but Julienne is not able to satisfy all the demand, given her limited financial means. For this reason Julienne is seeking a fourth loan in order to build up her business and better satisfy her customers.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn and fresh fish

loans.name: Rosette

texts.en: Rosette is 30 years old and married with three children aged between three and seven years. All her children go to school. She lives in her rented two- room house where she stays with four people. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. The family has three meals a day. Her three greatest expenses in a month are utility bills, school fees for her children and rent for her residence and business premises. Rosette has a stall in Owino Market, one of the ladies salons in Kasubi, working on all types of hair whether it's weaving, relaxing or plaiting. She also sells cosmetics. She works seven days a week. She serves about 10 customers a day. She has done this business for six years now. Her main challenges are the rainy season (which disturbs her a lot because she works from an open place, which hinders her customers from reaching her) and the ever- increasing prices of cosmetics.  She has been with MCDT for three years, servicing her sixth loan working all this long with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of conditioning creams and hair relaxers. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to start a bridal salon

loans.use: To buy more conditioning creams and relaxers

loans.name: Anasthasie

texts.fr: K. Anasthasie est née en 1970 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Anasthasie s’est installée depuis 17 ans environs, à la Zone des Ambassades à Cotonou. Mariée à AFFOGNON Rémi, un mécanicien auto, Anasthasie est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Tous les enfants vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Anasthasie n’a pas été à l’école. Pour venir en aide à son mari, Anasthasie vend de la bouillie (faite à base de maïs) à son domicile. Anasthasie vend également du riz, ce qui lui permet d’avoir plusieurs sources de revenus. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Anasthasie s’approvisionne, et elle mène cette activité depuis trois ans. Anasthasie a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. La clientèle de Anasthasie s’accroît au jour le jour et Anasthasie n’arrive plus à satisfaire tous les besoins. C’est pour renforcer son capital et élever le niveau de son activité que Anasthasie sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
K. Anasthasie was born in 1970 in Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. Anasthasie has lived for about seventeen years in the Zone des Ambassades in Cotonou. Married to AFFOGNON Rémi, an auto mechanic, Anasthasie is the mother of four children, all in school. All of the children live with their parents. The couple supports the family together. Anasthasie has never been to school. In order to help her husband, Anasthasie sells porridge (made from corn) from her home. Anasthasie also sells rice, which allows her to have several sources of income. Anasthasie gets her supplies in Dantokpa, international market of Benin, and she has been in this business for three years. Anasthasie has already received three loans from ALIDé, loans which she has fully repaid. Anasthasie's clientele grows every day, and she is no longer able to satisfy everyone's needs. In order to increase her working capital and raise the level of her business, Anasthasie is seeking a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn, sugar, and milk

loans.name: Gustavo Adolfo

texts.es:
El  Señor. Gustavo Adolfo B. R., Labora como Oficial de  Mantenimiento en el Instituto Manuel Olivares  de Managua, el es casado  tiene cuatro hijos a su cargo tres de ellos se encuentran en edad escolar, ha trabajado un créditos con CEPRODEL durante un año, en este periodo de tiempo ha invertido un crédito en la mejoramiento de la vivienda en la que habita, gracias a los financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción como: varios pliegos de zinc  para el techo de la casa.
texts.en:
Gustavo Adolfo B. R. works as a maintenance man at Managua's Manuel Olivares Institute. He is married and has four children, three of whom are still school-age, under his care. He has had loans with CEPRODEL for a year which he has used to make home improvements to his house. The funding requested is to buy several sheets of zinc metal sheeting for his roof.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make home improvements.

loans.name: Alioune

texts.fr:
Monsieur Alioune M. est un jeune célibataire de 33 ans très dynamique qui évolue dans la vente d’articles de mercerie depuis 10 ans. Il est sociétaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC Ouakam depuis 2007. Il a choisi ce commerce par amour du métier. Monsieur M.  sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs. L’objet de son crédit est l’achat de produits de mercerie dans le but de renforcer son stock de marchandise et de mieux diversifier ses articles. Monsieur M. a déjà bénéficié  de 2 crédits antérieurs qui ont participe a l’élargissement de son activité ce qui lui a permis d’acquérir certains biens personnels.
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  à exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique   apprécié.
texts.en:
Mr Alioune M., aged 33, is a young and highly dynamic single man who has been selling haberdashery items for ten years. He joined the Ouakam branch of the microfinance institution U-IMCEC in 2007. He chose this activity because of his love for this trade. Mr M. applies for a loan of 500,000 CFA francs. He will use it to buy haberdashery items in order to boost his inventory and diversify his supply. He was already the beneficiary of two loans which helped him to expand his business. As a result of this he was able to buy a few personal items. Always looking to actively participate in the fight against poverty, U-IMCEC – with the positive support of lenders – succeeds in supporting people in revenue-generating activities which promote valuable socioeconomic development.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: United Sisters Group

texts.en:
Victoria T. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Sisters. She is 40 years old and is married with six children aged from one year seven months old to 20 years old.  Victoria also cares for a niece.  Many of her children are in school, and their educational levels are nursery school to 7th grade.  Victoria herself only recently finished high school by taking classes at night school.  When she was younger she had to stop her schooling because of poverty.

Victoria and her family live in the Pipeline Community, and she works in the Red Light Market, Liberia's largest market which is near the capital, Monrovia.  Her business is the sale of fruit, such as plantain, bananas, oranges, etc. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail from a table in the Red Light Market.  She has been running this business for more than 20 years and hopes to become an exporter of Liberian plantain, banana, oranges and other fruit.

Victoria originally started her business with 500 Liberian Dollars as her working capital but with hard work, her business has grown.  She sells good, ripe fruit in order to encourage her customers to continue buying from her.  Victoria needs this loan to purchase more fruit for her business.

She dreams of being able to help educate her children so that they have a good foundation for their future.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Victoria is the one holding the sign.  Despite the group's name -- United Sisters -- there is one male member, Sungar S., who joined after the initial members had decided on the name.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell

loans.name: Blanca Rosa

texts.es:
La   Señora Blanca Rosa García, Labora como Afanadora en la Universidad Nacional Autónoma de Nicaragua, ella es casado  tiene un hijo a su cargo este se encuentran en edad escolar, ha trabajado un créditos con CEPRODEL durante un año, en este periodo de tiempo ha invertido un crédito en la mejoramiento de la vivienda en la que habita, gracias a los financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la  Construcción de un cuarto de habitación por lo que comprara materiales de construcción como: varios pliegos de zinc  para el techo, piedra, cemento.
texts.en:
Blanca Rosa García works as a janitor at the National Autonomous University of Nicaragua. She is married and has one child in her care, who is of school age. She has had one previous loan with CEPRODEL in the past year, and during that period of time, she has invested the funds from that loan in improving the home where she lives, thanks to the financing provided by CEPRODEL. The loan she is currently requesting will be invested in the construction of an additional room in her home. The funds will be used to purchase construction materials such as stone, cement and several zinc sheets for the roof.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improving and expanding her home

loans.name: Mery Del Carmen

texts.es:
La  Señora  Mery del Carmen Pérez Martínez, Labora como  Conserje en el Instituto Manuel Olivares de Managua.                                                                                                                                                                            Ella es casado  tiene dos hijos a su cargo y  estos se encuentran en edad escolar, ha trabajado dos créditos con CEPRODEL durante dos años, en este periodo de tiempo ha invertido dos  crédito en la mejoramiento de la vivienda en la que habita, gracias a los financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de  materiales de construcción como: piso y cemento para su casa de habitación.
Mery dijo que gracias a los préstamos otorgados por ceprodel ha venido mejorando su casa de habitación, por lo que ahora cuenta con una casa más segura para su familia.
texts.en:
Mery del Carmen Pérez Martínez works as a caretaker at Managua's Manuel Olivares Institute. She is married and has two, school-age, children under her care. She has had two loans with CEPRODEL that she has used to improve her home. The financing requested now will be used to buy building materials like flooring and cement for her home. Mery told us that, thanks to CEPRODEL's loans, she has been making improvements to her home which has led to her having a safer home for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make home improvements.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Donald Miguel

texts.es:
El    Señor Donald Miguel García A., Labora como  Comprador en el Teatro Nacional Rubén Darío,                                                                                                                                                                                                  el es casado  tiene cuatro  hijos a su cargo y  estos se encuentran en edad escolar, ha trabajado cuatro créditos con CEPRODEL durante cinco año, en este periodo de tiempo ha invertido cuatro crédito en la mejoramiento de la vivienda en la que habita, gracias a los financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de  materiales de construcción como: piso y cemento para du casa de habitación.
Donald dijo que gracias a los prestamos otorgados por ceprodel ha venido mejorando su casa de habitación, por lo que ahora cuenta con una casa mas segura para su familia.
texts.en:
Donald Miguel García A. is a buyer for the Rubén Darío National Theater. He is married and has four, school age, children under his care. He has had four loans with CEPRODEL over five years that he has used to make improvement on his home. The funding requested now will be used to buy building materials, like flooring and cement, for his home. Donald stated that thanks to loans from CEPRODEL he has been able to make improvements to his home to the extent that now he has a safer home for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make home improvements.

loans.name: Honorine

texts.fr: Née le 15 Juillet 1984 à So-Ava dans le département de l'Atlantique, S. Honorine est mariée à ATINDOGBE Florent. Le couple a six enfants à charge, dont trois sont leurs propres enfants. Seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit depuis 8 ans environs à Godomey dans la commune d'Abomey-Calavi. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par le couple. Honorine a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au cours secondaire, puis a appris la coiffure. Honorine exerce cette activité depuis près de 8 ans, une activité qui lui génère de revenu qu'elle utilise pour satisfaire ses différents besoins. Parallèlement à cette activité, Honorine vend des mêches et des produits de beauté dans son atelier situé à Godomey. Honorine s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Honorine a obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien effectué les remboursements. Honorine sollicite un deuxième crédit afin de renforcer son activité et de mieux faire face aux différents besoins des clients.
texts.en:
Born July 15, 1984 in So-Ava in the department of the Atlantic, Honorine S. is married to Florent ATINDOGBE. The couple have six children under their care, of which three are their own. Only some of the children are educated. The family has been living for approximately eight years in the Abomey-Calavi area. The couple share household expenses. Honorine attended school up to secondary level, then learned hairdressing. She has been practicing this trade for the past eight years, which generates income to meet her different needs. Additionally, Honorine sells hair extensions and beauty products in her beauty salon located in Godomey. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Honorine has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, and reimbursed it in full. She now requests a second loan to bolster her business and better respond to her customers’ diverse needs.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy two dozen hair extensions and two cartons of shampoo.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy sewing machines

loans.name: Unity Group

texts.en: Andrew F. is the leader of Unity, a group of five borrowers. He is 34 years old and married with two children, aged 5 and 10. His older child is in the 3rd grade and the younger one is not in school yet. Andrew himself is a high school graduate. Besides his children, Andrew also cares for siblings. Andrew started his business selling hardware, such as nails, screws and padlocks, five years ago with about 2,800 Liberian dollars in capital. He sells from a table in the Red Light Market, Liberia's largest market, which is near the capital Monrovia. With his 6,000 Liberian dollar share of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan, Andrew intends to buy more inventory for his business. Andrew says he competes well because he has good products which he sells at good prices. He hopes to grow his business and one day open a proper storefront. He wants to be successful enough to be able to help pay for a good education for his children. In the composite photo that accompanies this profile, Andrew is the one the middle. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy hardware, such as nails, padlocks and other items

loans.name: Aleyda Del Socorro

texts.es:
En el municipio de Villanueva en el departamento de Chinandega, la señora Aleyda R. se ha desempeñado como maestra de educación primaria en un pequeño colegio del municipio donde a diario ella imparte clase a los pequeños con el propósito de obtener los ingresos necesarios para el mantenimiento de su hogar.
Ella es soltera y tiene a su cargo el cuido y protección de su mamá por lo que el crédito lo está solicitando para la compra de los medicamentos de su mamá que ha estado un poco afectada de salud pero Aleyda tiene las esperanzas de que mejorará. Espera que el crédito sea otorgado y así mejorará las condiciones de vida de su amada madre.
texts.en:
Aleyda R. works as an elementary school teacher in a small elementary school in Villanueva, Chinandega department. She imparts knowledge every day to the children hoping to earn enough income to support her household. She is single but has her mother's care and protection in her hands. The loan requested is to buy medicines for her mother who has been a bit unwell. Aleyda hopes, however, that she will recover. She hopes that the loan will be approved so that her dear mother's living conditions will improve.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy medicine for her mother.

loans.name: Ayaba

texts.fr: G. Ayaba est née le 23 Juin 1966 à Ouidah dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Ayaba s'est installée à Godomey dans la commune d'Abomey-Calavi, il y a 17 ans environs. Mariée à GBESSINON Omer, Ayaba est mère de trois enfants. Le couple a deux autres enfants à charge. Certains enfants sont scolarisés. Les dépenses de la famille sont supportées par le couple. Ayaba n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour assurer ses charges et venir en aide à son mari, Ayaba mène comme activité, la vente d'huile d'arachide et d'huile de palme à son domicile. Parallèlement à cette activité, Ayaba a complété la vente de sachets et de sucre en poudre, ce qui lui permet d'avoir une autre source de revenu. Ayaba mène cette activité depuis 12 ans environs et s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Ayaba a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit auprès de ALIDé et a bien remboursé le crédit. Actuellement Ayaba ne dispose pas suffisamment de fonds pouvant lui permettre de satisfaire tous ses clients et de se faire plus de revenus à la hauteur de ses différentes charges. C'est donc pour renforcer son activité que Ayaba sollicite un deuxième crédit.
texts.en:
Ayaba G. was born June 23, 1966 in Ouidah, in the Department of the Atlantic of Benin. She settled approximately 17 years ago in Godomey, in the area of Abomey-Calavi. Married to Omer GBESSINON, Ayaba is mother of three children, but the couple have two other children under their care. Some of the children are educated. The couple share family expenses. Ayaba has not attended school. To meet her expenses and assist her husband, Ayaba sells peanut and palm nut oil from her home. She also sells plastic bags and powdered sugar, which provides her with an additional source of income. Ayaba has been doing this for the past 12 years, and gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Ayaba has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, and reimbursed it in full. She currently lacks the funds necessary to satisfy all her customers and generate sufficient profit to cover her various expenses. Therefore, Ayaba is requesting a second loan to bolster her activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 5 jerrycans of peanut and palm nut oil, two bags of sugar.

loans.name: Angel

texts.es:
Ángel tiene 37 años, es una persona muy tranquila y alegre. Vive solo en su casa propia y lo que más desea es salir adelante y mejorar su calidad de vida.

Desde que tenía 17 años decidió estudiar odontología en la universidad y posteriormente implementó su consultorio para ayudar a todas las personas que lo necesitaran. Su consultorio está muy cerca de uno de los mercados más importantes de la ciudad y actualmente atiende a muchas personas, las cuales, debido a su ubicación, son en su mayoría comerciantes.
Por otro lado, lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es atender a las personas que realmente necesitan de sus cuidados, ya que pone toda su atención en ellos. Lleva 10 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tratar a los niños, ya que lloran mucho y muchas veces no lo dejan concentrarse como debe, pero aun así sabe que ese es el trabajo que eligió y está dispuesto a seguir trabajado duro para sacarlo adelante. 
Con el tiempo, espera que su negocio crezca y le pueda brindar mejores ingresos económicos.

Este es el cuarto préstamo de Ángel con MFP y al igual como hizo con sus primeros créditos, espera pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo. En su banco comunal es un socio muy tranquilo y siempre está al tanto de los acuerdos tomados. Con los mil trescientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará material odontológico para atender mejor a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Ángel is 37-years-old and is a very calm and happy person. He lives alone in his own home and what he desires most is to succeed and improve his quality of life. At 17, he decided to study dentistry in college and has since started his own practice so that he could help people in need. His practice is very close to one of the most important markets in his city, and currently serves many people, whom, because of his location, are mostly merchants.

On the other hand, what he likes most about his work is serving those who really need his services, so that he may give them all his attention. He has been in this line of work for 10 years and considers the most difficult part to be treating children because they cry a lot and many times this breaks his concentration. Still, he knows that this is the job he chose and he is ready to continue working hard to be able to succeed. With time, he hopes that his business will grow so that he can increase his income.

This is Ángel's fourth loan with MFP (Microfinanzas Prisma), and just like with his earlier loans, he hopes to make all his payments on time. In his communal bank, he is a very calm member and he is always aware of the agreements reached. With the loan he has requested, Ángel will buy dental tools that will help him better serve his patients.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy dental tools

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr: Née en 1981 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, S. Véronique réside depuis environs 15 ans au quartier Logbozounkpa à Cotonou. Véronique est mariée à ADJANOUGBETA Yves et est mère de trois enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Véronique vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule leurs différentes charges. Pour y parvenir, Véronique vend du maïs dans son quartier, et ce depuis 6 ans. C'est à Adja au Mono que Véronique s'approvisionne. Véronique n'a jamais obtenu de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Véronique sollicite un premier prêt pour augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux satisfaire la demande des clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1981 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. S. Véronique has been residing for about fifteen years in the Logbozounkpa district of Cotonou.  She is married to Mr. ADJANOUGBETA Yves and is the mother of three children.  All of the children are in school.  She lives alone with her children, and she covers their various expenses by herself. To do so, she has been selling corn in her area for six years.  She supplies herself in Adja in Mono.  Véronique has never obtained a loan from ALIDé.  Facing the increasing number of customer demands, she is requesting an initial loan to increase her stock of supplies and to satisfy customer demand better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 40 sacs of corn

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es:
Beatriz, de 47 años, es una mujer muy alegre y sincera, vive en su casa propia y está dispuesta a trabajar muy duro para sobre salir en la vida.

Su tienda de abarrotes es una de las más visitadas en su barrio, desde muy temprano por la mañana abre su tienda en espera de que sus clientes lleguen a comprar las cosas que necesitan. Ella es una vendedora muy alegre y atenta, ya que siempre recibe a sus clientes con una sonrisa y está dispuesta ayudarlos en sus compras.
Por otro lado, lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus clientes, lleva 20 años en este negocio y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día dentro de su tienda sin poder salir. 
Con el tiempo, espera ampliar su bodega y abastecerla de más mercadería para ofrecer a sus clientes una mejor variedad de productos.

Este es el octavo préstamo de Beatriz con MFP y está dispuesta a pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo, ya que no quiere causarle problemas a su banco comunal, donde es muy querida por el resto de sus compañeras. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más productos para implementar mejor su tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Beatriz, 47, is a very happy and sincere woman. She lives in her own house, and she is prepared to work very hard to succeed in life. Her grocery store is one of the busiest in her neighborhood. She opens her store very early in the morning, waiting for her customers to come and buy the things they need. She is a very happy and attentive salesperson. She always receives her customers with a smile and is ready to help them with their purchases. What she likes most about her work is talking with her customers. She has been in this business for 20 years. The most difficult part is having to stay in her store all day without being able to leave. In time she hopes to expand her convenience store and stock it with more merchandise to offer her customers a better variety of products. This is Beatriz’s eighth loan with MFP. She is prepared to make all of her payments on time because she does not want to cause problems for her communal bank. She is much loved by her colleagues in her communal bank. She will use the 1,000 PEN she is requesting to buy more products to better set up her grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Santiago

texts.es:
El señor Santiago C. vive en el municipio de Villanueva donde se ha dedicado a trabajar en la siembra de ajonjolí desde hace varios años y ha logrado mejorar las condiciones de su casa de habitación beneficiando a sus tres hijos en edad escolar y brindándoles un techo digno donde habitar.
Él se levanta muy temprano para irse a la finca y atender los cultivos y la esposa se dedica a trabajar como maestra de alumnos de primaria la cual la jornada comienza desde las 7:00 de la mañana.
Actualmente, el señor Santiago está solicitando un crédito para invertirlo en la siembra del ajonjolí y así tener una buena cosecha y continuar mejorando las condiciones de vida de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Santiago C. lives in Villanueva where he has been a sesame farmer for several years. He has managed to make home improvements, which have been of benefit to his three, school-age, children, by providing them with a proper home in which to live. He rises very early to go to his fields and tend to his crops. His wife is an elementary school teacher who starts her work day at 7am. Currently, Santiago is asking for funding to invest in his sesame crops so that his harvest will be good and he can continue to improve his children's living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in sesame crops.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es:
Elsa, de 46 años, es una mujer muy luchadora y alegre, vive en su casa propia junto a su hijo Marco, de 10 años, y lo que más desea es darle una buena educación.
Su ferretería es una de las más concurridas de la ciudad, su gran carisma y paciencia para atender a sus clientes han hecho de ella una vendedora muy querida. Desde muy temprano se levanta para abrir su negocio, ya que sabe que por las mañanas es cuando mayor demanda tiene.
