loans.name: Marissa

texts.en: Marissa A., a 31-year-old  fish vendor, works from early morning until late afternoon to be able to sell her fish and earn income for her family. She desires a good future for her family, and despite its difficulties, her business helps her pay all of the expenses in their home. She is now applying for a loan of Php 6,000 to buy fishing materials to be used by her husband as well as fish that she can resell in the town market.

loans.use: To obtain additional fishing materials for fishing and to buy fish to resell

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie B. is a resident of Libis, Binangonan, Rizal. She is 46 years old and a mother to four sons. She is education-oriented and makes sure her four children attend school regularly. Two of her children are college students, one is at high school, and the youngest is at elementary school. Rosemarie is married to Ricardo B., a barber and a supportive husband.
Rosemarie is busy retailing a variety of small items, a business she finds very productive. She learned the business from experience and using her own initiative in dealing with costumers. The proceeds of her business are a big help to the family, especially in meeting the educational needs of the children. Now Rosemarie is requesting a loan of 19,000 PHP from Kiva partner, ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.). She will use the loan to buy volume stocks of different goods for her retail business.
Rosemarie's ambition is that her four children will be able to finish their schooling with a degree and find stable jobs. She and her husband have also a great dream of investing in a piece of land and building a house of their own. They have rented for almost 15 years now, which is why it is hard for them to save money. Rosemarie is hoping that, with ASHI's support, there is a big possibility that they can fulfill their dreams.

loans.use: To buy stocks of a variety of goods to retail

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 40 years of age, married with four children aged 6 and 15 years. All her children go to school. The family resides and rents  a one roomed house where she stays with seven people. She doesn’t take care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity and no piped water at home.  The family has two meals a day.

Agnes' three greatest monthly expenses includes paying utility bills, school fees for children and rent for business and residence. Agnes operates a bar in Kamwokya Kifumbira selling all types of beers and liquors and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week and serves about twenty customers a day. She has done this business for over seven years.

Agnes' main challenges are transportation and the rainy season which disturbs her a lot because she works from an muddy place which hinders her customers to reach out to her and also ever increasing prices of beers and alcohol in Uganda .  She has been with MCDT for ten years and has taken out twenty loans, working all this long with the same borrowing group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of alcohol. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and wants to start a fully stocked bar

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of local gin /alcohol.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace C. is currently in the business of selling pealed dried cassava and sweet potatoes in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase beans and maize flour to sell. Grace is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a clerk. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a little restaurant at the market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase beans and maize flour to add to her inventory

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda B. is from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She is 41 years old. Esmeralda is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Esmeralda owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Esmeralda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Esmeralda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esmeralda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28000 PHP from ASKI. Esmeralda is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Esmeralda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita H. is a 31-year-old woman from the coastal town of Talim Island, Rizal Province, in the Philippines. She is a mother to three children. All of them are minors and grade school students. She is married to a fisherman, Risaldy, who is 45 years old.

For her new loan, she is requesting 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her fish pond and fish-vending business. From the fish pond, she delivers different types of fish to nearby towns, where it is consumed by customers.

In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. She was full of aspirations to uplift her family from poverty. Now that she has the chance to complete her dreams, she hopes to have more fish ponds to produce more fish to sell in the nearby village. She also wants to reconstruct their house that was destroyed in the huge storm of typhoon” Ondoy”.

loans.use: additional working capital for her fish pond and fish vending business

loans.name: Y. Marie-Madeleine

texts.fr: A. Y. Marie-Madeleine est née le 29 Mai 1965 à Dassa-Zoumé dans le département des Collines au Bénin. Mariée à EZIN K. Jérémie, Marie-Madeleine est mère de cinq enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille s'est installée à Dogoudo à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique, il y a 2 ans environs. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Marie-Madeleine a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Marie-Madeleine mène comme activité, la vente de divers produits (pâtes alimentaires, conserves de tomate, lait, sardine, savons, oeufs, etc.) à Allada. Marie-Madeleine vend de façon secondaire, les produits de poissonnerie. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Marie-Madeleine se ravitaille. Marie-Madeleine a obtenu une fois déjà de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Désireuse d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et d'élever le niveau de son activité, Marie-Madeleine sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé en vue de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
A. Y. Marie-Madeleine was born on May 29, 1965 in Dassa-Zoumé in the province 'Collines' in Bénin. Married to EZIN K. Jérémie, Marie-Madeleine is the mother of 5 children, who are all enrolled in school. The family came to live in Dogoudo in Allada, in the province 'Atlantique' about two years ago. The couple share in supporting the family.

Marie-Madeleine left school when she reached secondary level. To support herself, she sells various items (pasta, tinned tomatoes, milk, sardines, soap, eggs, etc.) in Allada. As a secondary business, she also sells fish. She stocks up in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. Marie-Madeleine has already received one loan from ALIDé. Wishing to add to her working capital and bolster the level of her business, she is requesting a second loan from ALIDé so as to better satisfy her clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of pasta, tinned foods, trays of eggs, and soap

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 48 years of age, a single mother of four children aged 10 to 23 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a five-roomed house where she lives with six people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for children, and medication.

Mary sells vegetables in Kawempe growers' market and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. She serves about fifty customers a day. She has done this business for over twelve years. Her main challenges are transportation and the rainy season which disturbs her a lot because she works from a muddy place which hinders her customers from reaching out to her.

Besides this vegetable business, Mary also sells sweet and Irish potatoes She has been with MCDT for nine years, servicing her eighteenth loan, working all this long time with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of vegetables. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting going directly to farmers.

loans.use: To buy more  boxes of vegetables and fruits

loans.name: Lilibeth's Group

texts.en:
Lilibeth A. is from the village of Union, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 35 years old. Lilibeth is the group leader of a 17-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lilibeth is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns & operates a general store where she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lilibeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Lilibeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Group -3

texts.en:
Indunil is the group leader of her group and she 30 years old. She is married and living with her husband. She has one daughter.  Her business is doing tailoring, and for now she wants to expand her business and create some employment in the village for other women. She is a very hard working women and has all the quality needed to be a economically self-sufficient women.

Kusumalatha is another member of Indunils group. She is 48 years old, married and living with her husband.  They don't have any child. Both husband and wife are running a business together. They want improve their business and so will buy some materials for designing dresses with their loan.

Demor is the another member of same group. She is 28 years old, married but living alone. Her husband is a migrant worker living outside the country. Right now, Demor has 20 poultry birds and is running a small poultry business. She wants to develop this business more and so she is dreaming of employing other people in her business. She dreams of being a successful business women and so she is working hard for that.

Manoratna is the another member of same group. She is 40 years old, married living with her husband. She has two children who are married and living on their own. Her husband does not have regular job, so she is the one who has to provide for both of them. Manoratna is also a tailor and needs support to run her business so she can live a happy and poverty free life with her husband.

Kanty is also a member of this group. She is 58 years old  and married living with her husband. She has three children. Two of them are living on their own and one is living with her. They have their small food processing business to maintain their family's livelihood. They make different type of local snacks and sweets. Kanty needs this loans to develop her business, so she can take of her family and her daughter's education.

loans.use: Material for making clothing

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria A., 42 years old, married, is a member of Ginoong Sanay center of Rizal South Branch (RSB). She is also an active member of her group and center. She lives in a coastal place called Talim Island, Binangonan, Rizal, Philippines. The couple is blessed with an only child, Jennilyn A., a 9-year-old grade III student. Like many families, they want to uplift themselves and get away from poverty. They come from poor families themselves and they want a better life for their child.

In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, to obtain working capital to her primary business fishing. Now on her third loan, she requests 15,000 PHP to start hog-fattening as her secondary source of income. The loan funds will be used to purchase 4 piglets, feed, vitamins and pay transportation expenses. The remaining money will also be used to reconstruct her fishing business which was destroyed by typhoon ”Ondoy”.

In the future, Gloria wants to invest in their own pump boat. She hopes to have success with both businesses in order to provide quality education for her child until she finishes college. Gloria also enjoys seeing that the loan from ASHI and KIVA will change their lives and gradually allow her to touch her dreams.

loans.use: To pay for 4 piglets, feed, vitamins and transportation expenses, and reconstruct her fishing business

loans.name: Marsellar

texts.en: Marsellar is 48 years old, married and has nine children. Her husband is a pastor and they hope to expand her business and even open other restaurants. Her business is located within Kakamega town where she sells food and beverages to the local people. She has been in this business for five years and her major challenge has been competition. Previously she was a fishmonger and it is when doing this business that the idea of a restaurant was born. Her major challenge is that there are so many people doing the same kind of business as hers but she is determined to be the best. She is using her loan to buy flour, maize, beans and sugar. In the future, she wants to buy her own plot. She describes herself as very hardworking and visionary.

loans.use: To buy flour, maize, beans and sugar

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores R. is from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She is 58 years old. Dolores is widowed and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Dolores owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Dolores has been engaged in her business for over 40 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Dolores joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dolores has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from ASKI. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Dolores from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of their family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Set up his workshop and buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Agossoussi

texts.fr: Née en 1968 à TOFFO à Allada dans le département de l'Atlantique, T. Agossoussi y vit depuis sa naissance. Agossoussi est mariée à HOUNGNINOU Alphonse et est mère de deux enfants, mais a un autre enfant à charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Agossoussi vit seule avec ses enfants et assure toute seule leurs charges. Pour subvenir à tous ses besoins et assurer l'entretien et l'éducation des enfants, Agossoussi vend du maïs à Sey à Allada. Parallèlement à cette activité, Agossoussi vend de la farine de manioc communément appelée "gari", ce qui lui permet d'avoir une autre source de revenu. Agossoussi s'approvisionne au marché de Sey et de Houègbo à Allada. Agossoussi mène cette activité depuis 24 ans et a bénéficié déjà de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé. Agossoussi a bien remboursé les deux crédits. Agossoussi ambitionne agrandir davantage son activité pour mieux faire face à sa clientèle et se faire plus de revenus à la hauteur de ses charges. Mais par manque de moyens financiers pour atteindre ses objectifs, Agossoussi sollicite un troisème prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1968 in Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic, Agossoussi T. has lived there since her birth. She is married to Alphonse HOUNGNINOU, and is the mother of two children with another child under her care. All the children are educated. Agossoussi lives alone with her children and is their sole provider. To meet all her needs and ensure proper care and education for her children, Agossoussi sells corn in the Sey area of Allada. Additionally, she sells cassava flour – commonly called ‘gari’ – which provides her with another source of income. Agossoussi gets her supplies from local markets in Allada (Sey and Honègbo). Agossoussi has been running this business for 24 years and has already been granted two loans by ALIDé, both of which were fully reimbursed. She wants to expand her activities to better meet her customer’s expectations and generate enough revenue to meet her needs. As she lacks the financial means to reach her objectives, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 10 bags of corn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy hair extensions

loans.name: Rael

texts.en: Rael is a 25-year-old woman, whose husband works for Akamba Bus Company. She has two children, one of whom is in school. She has been running her business, Bop C Shop, where she sells sugar, fat, rice, soap, tea leaves and other items, since 2004. With the Kes. 75,000 loan, she wants to increase stock for her shop. Her other source of income is a green-grocery.  She hopes to improve her business to help boost her family's standard of living. She wants to grow her business to the wholesale level in the future. Rael describes herself as hard-working and promising.

loans.use: To increase stock in sugar, fat, rice, soap, tea leaves and cereals

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline A. M. is 37 years old, married and has six children. Her husband is a businessman and they hope to buy land of their own some day. She makes a living in Kakamega selling clothes, shoes and cosmetics. She has been doing this for one year and despite many challenges -- including a large number of competitors -- she is determined to grow her business. As time permits, she also helps run a farm. She has applied for this loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more clothes, shoes and cosmetics to sell. She is very hardworking and visionary.

loans.use: Clothes, shoes and cosmetics.

loans.name: Mirvah

texts.en: Mirvah is a 37-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, Lebanon's capital, with her husband and their one child. For the last two years, she has made a living selling jewelry, including necklaces, earrings, bracelets, and handmade items, and her customers are largely friends and neighbors. She has applied for her first loan from Al Majmoua to buy more jewelry to sell. When she started her business, she was happy with her income, but now she would like to expand it to better support her family. In the future, she hopes to continue expanding her small company.

loans.use: To buy more jewelery to sell.

loans.name: Evans

texts.en: Evans S. M. is 37 years old, married and has two children. For the last three years, he and his wife have made a living selling shoes. They work hard because they are committed to paying for the education of their children through the university level. The couple run their business in an open air market, and are not able to work when it rains. But when the weather permits, they work from early morning to late evening so that they can earn enough money to someday open up an indoor shop that can be open every day. Evans has applied for this loan to buy additional shoes to sell to his customers. He is widely thought of as a very hardworking and ambitious man.

loans.use: To buy additional shoes to sell to customers

loans.name: Turmunh

texts.en:
Turmunh is 27 years old and lives with his wife and infant daughter in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". His daughter attends kindergarten and his wife help with the family business.

Turmunh operates a shoe making business in his town. He specializes in making a variety of traditional Mongolian shoes and boots such as the "Buriad" and "Mongol".  He makes shoes that can be used both cold and hot weather. He started his business in 2008. He has worked hard to grow his business over the last two years in his rented apartment. With his business profit he enabled himself to buy a ger for his family.

He is focused on improving his skills as a shoemaker and growing his business. The most important thing to him is being able to provide for his children's education. He says, "I would be happy to hear about nice feeling from my customers." He is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (~420 USD) loan to purchase leather, glue, thread and other necessary material for his business.

loans.use: To purchase leather, glue, thread and other necessary materials for shoe and boot making.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Raw materials for coir making

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester E., 41 years old, desires for a better livelihood for her family. Currently she tills a small parcel of rice field to be able to earn an income for her family. She also raises a sow to produce piglets which she sells.

She has been dreaming to improve her harvest, especially because her three children are all going to school and she must help pay for their school fees. She wants this loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos from Kiva field partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and fertilizer and pig feed as well.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pig feed.

loans.name: Marebelle

texts.en: Marebelle L., 29 years old, is a food vendor. She desires to be able to earn a bigger income so that she can help her husband buy their family food and other basic necesities. She has three children and she is doing the very best she can to be able to augment their harvest to support their education. Marebelle wanted to venture into another business aside from having a farm. Now, she would like to apply for a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy food ingredients to add to the dishes in her eatery business.

loans.use: Buy additional ingredients for eatery dishes

loans.name: Marvin

texts.en: Marvin E., 22 years old, is engaged in a fish selling business. He is a young fisherman from Talibon, Bohol and he works every day to catch fish to help his family have an adequate supply of food, clothing and other basic needs. He desires to have a bigger income in the family. He would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy fishing materials.

loans.use: Buy fishing materials

loans.name: Victor

texts.en: Victor R., 40 years old, is a fisherman in Talibon Bohol. Every day, he goes out to the sea to catch fish. His livelihood is what he relies on for food, clothes and other basic needs of the family. He wants to buy more fish to resell and hopes that some day he will be able to increase the size of his earnings. He wanted to buy new fishing materials, which is why he hopes to receive a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to support his livelihood.

loans.use: To obtain fishing materials and fish to resell

loans.name: Enhtuya

texts.en: Enhtuya is 49 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Tuv province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent called “ger”. Her oldest son and daughter, 21 and 22, attend university while the youngest is in secondary school. Her husband is a driver who operates a taxi service. She operates a hair salon with the help of her three friends in her town. She has been a hairdresser since 1979 and worked at a private hair saloon until opening her own business. She started her business in 2006 and since then has stabilized her business operation over the years. Her hair saloon is well known amongst residents of Tuv province. She attributes her business success to the good location of her hair salon. With her business earnings she started constructing a house in her yard.  She is open-minded and a hardworking business woman who has lots of plans for the future.   She says, “All I want is to have my children to be educated and have nice life.” She is requesting a 1,900,000 tugrugs (~1340 USD) loan to pay her two children's tuition fees and to buy tools and equipment needed in her hair salon business.

loans.use: To buy tools and equipment for the hair salon, and pay children's tuition

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en: Reynaldo D., 39 years old, is engaged in fish retail. He is a fisherman and he raises his family by selling his own catch. He also buys fish from other fishermen and resells it to the next town. He started his business when he was just a teenager since he learned how to fish at a very early age.  He joined CEVI in 2009 and likes the program. This is the reason why he would like to re-apply for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will really help him obtain more fish to resell.

loans.use: To buy fish to resell

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy is a 28-year-old married man with two children who both attend school. He has been running his retail shop, where he sells clothes, shoes, and various other items, for two years and was previously employed at City Council. His other source of income is from offering transport services with his motorbike.

With the KES 30,000 loan, Kennedy wants to purchase mobile phone accessories. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for teaching him how to manage and maintain income from his business. He hopes to expand his boutique in the future and open up other businesses.

Kennedy describes himself as creative and loyal.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phone accessories for his shop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ganhuyag

texts.en:
Ganhuyag is 53 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Tuv province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". His oldest son, aged 26, is a driver and his youngest two daughters, aged 19 and 21, are university students.

Ganhuyag operates a grocery shop in his town where he sells a variety of foodstuffs such as flour, rice, canned fruit, vegetables, etc. He started his business in 2000 with working capital of 500,000 tugrugs (~350 USD).

Ganhuyag has made much progress with his new business over the past ten years and has built good relationships amongst both his many customers and his suppliers. He has a very positive outlook for his business and always treats his customers with respect. Today, his working capital exceeds 4,000,000 tugrugs (~2800 USD).

Growing his business is very important to Ganhuyag and he says, "I want to expand my business for the future." He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase candies, biscuits, sugar and other products for his business.

loans.use: To purchase candies, biscuits, sugar, and other products for his business

loans.name: Marie Dorothy

texts.en:
Marie Dorothy P. lives the village of Bugo, Cagayan de Oro city. She is 44 years old, married and has four grown children. For the last three years, she has made a living selling food, primarily snacks and other delicacies. Marie Dorothy has been in business for more than three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from her work.

Last year, Marie Dorothy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and business. She has successfully repaid two prior loans of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which she used to buy ingredients to make products to sell. She is applying for a new loan of 11,000 PHP to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City, and reaches out to poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her small business

location.town: Bugo, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Florida's Group

texts.en:
Florida D. G. lives in the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 34 years old, and leads a 17-member loan group through ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Florida is married and has two school-aged children. She makes a living by running a general store where she sells shampoo, soap and toothpaste to people in her local community. Florida has been engaged in business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from her work.

Last year, she joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and business. Florida has applied for her third, for 7,000 PHP, to expand her small store. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines and has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand several small businesses

loans.name: Marcelline

texts.fr: Née le 25 Avril 1962 à Allada dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin, Z. Marcelline vit depuis sa naissance au quartier Ayouhangnan à Allada. Mariée à TCHETCHE Ambroise un douanier, Marcelline est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Marcelline n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Marcelline vend des tissus à Ayou à Allada. C'est au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin, et à Allada, que Marcelline s'approvisionne. Marcelline a 5 ans d'expérience dans cette activité et a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. Marcelline ambitionne élever le niveau de son activité et agrandir sa clientèle ; ce qui lui permettra de se faire plus de revenu à la hauteur de ses charges. C'est la raison pour laquelle Marcelline sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born April 25, 1962 in Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic of Benin, Marcelline Z. has always lived in the Ayouhangnan neighbourhood of Allada. Married to Ambroise TCHETCHE, a customs agent, Marcelline is the mother of three children, all educated. The couple share the household expenses. Marcelline has only attended primary school. To cover her various expenses, Marcelline sells fabrics in the Ayou area of Allada. She gets her supplies from Togo, a country adjacent to Benin, and from Allada. Marcelline has five years experience in this activity, and has already been granted one credit with ALIDé, which has been fully reimbursed. Marcelline’s ambition is to increase the level of her activity and expand her customer base. This will increase her earnings to a level consistent with her expenses. This is why she is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 10 pieces of fabric

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
Marieta is a 59 years old and lives in the 3rd class municipality of Morong, an attractive province of Rizal. She and her husband have three children, all of whom are legal age and college students. She is married to Jaime S., a 63-year-old electrician and a loving husband.

In 2000, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap Inc.) a microfinance institution and Kiva field partner in the Philippines. Marieta makes and sells peanut butter and coco jam (sweet delicacies). She has been in business for more than five years. She has learned this kind of business through business training and seminars she attended. Her products are display and available at INSOL (and NGO partner of ASHI that provides business development training to entrepreneurs) enterprise center. Sometimes her products are also available at INSOL trade fair booths in shopping malls.

Marieta believes this loan of 40,000 Philippine pesos will be a big help and will contribute to the growth of her business. She will use all of the loans funds to expand her business of peanut butter and coco jam making.

Marieta dreams of having a stall for her growing business. She wants her children to finish their studies and live in comfortable house.

loans.use: Additional working capital for a peanut butter and coco jam making business.

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en: Annabelle G. owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling food and daily use products in her community. She is 38 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from El Salvador City. Annabelle has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 50,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Annabelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase products to sell. Annabelle is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael is a 37-year-old married man with two sons, one of whom attends school. He has been collecting garbage and offering Mpesa (mobile banking) services since 1998 and employs four people. With the 50,000 Kenyan shilling loan, he hopes to improve his collection business. He hopes to purchase more trucks for his business to expand to other estates and open a dealership in the future. Michael describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy more trucks improve garbage collection services.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en: Luisa A. is from Barangay Ibung, a village in Villaberde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 45 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Luisa owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Luisa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from ASKI. Luisa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Roy

texts.en:
32-year-old Roy has three children. He is from Agusan Del Sur, a province in the Philippines where most people are engaged in agriculture. Roy himself is a rice farmer. He currently owns a one-hectare rice field, which he thanks God for because it provides income for his family. He hopes to grow the farm so he will be able to sustain his children’s education.

Roy recently joined Kiva field partner CEVI and is currently on his first loan cycle. He has requested a 6,000 Philippine peso loan and plans to use the proceeds to buy farm supplies. He says he likes CEVI’s program, especially because of its low interest rate.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita farms for a living. She is 54 years old, married and has nine children. Her oldest child, who is now 34 years old, does not live with the family any more. Teresita plants rice at her farm. She works hard at the farm to sustain her family’s needs. She helps her husband maintain the farm’s productivity. 

Teresita want a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos and plans to use it to buy seed, fertilizer, and other farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer, and other farm supplies

loans.name: Jeaneth

texts.en:
Jeaneth is engaged in rice farming. She has three hectares of rice field, which she and her husband patiently till. Aside from that, she is also has a hog-raising business and runs a small variety store from their house. Jeaneth is engaged in multiple businesses because she has to provide for her family’s growing needs. She has five children and her oldest is now 19 years old.

Jeaneth wants to get a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos, and plans to use the proceeds to buy farm supplies like seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies such as seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en: 35-year-old Geraldine is a married woman with three children. Her oldest child is now 16 years old. She is involved in rice farming. She works hard to make her farm productive. She wants to double her harvest in order to be able to earn more money.   She wants to be able to better provide for the growing needs in her household. She is seeking a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos, which she plans to use to buy fertilizer and other farming supplies.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farming supplies

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida tills a 2.5-hectare rice field. She is 46 years old, married and has five children. She works hard to cope with her family’s growing needs, especially her children’s education.

She and her husband were able to harvest 160 sacks of rice during their last harvest. She wants to maintain this level because sometimes, their harvest is less than that and it's difficult to make enough money. Leonida is requesting a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI to fund her farm. She will use it to acquire farm inputs like seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Romulo

texts.en:
Romulo is a rice farmer. At 61, he can still endure the work required at the farm. Although he has worked at the farm for most of his life, he still finds it enjoyable. He tills a 2-hectare rice field, which provides him with his income. He is a married man and has only one child who is now 22 years old.

Romulo would like to request a loan of PHP 6,000. He will use it to fund his farm: to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en: Salvacion owns a rice farm that her family relies upon for income. She is 40 years old, married and has two children. Her oldest is now 17 years old and goes to school. Her dreams for her children are for them to have a proper education and a bright future. She wants to expand her business in order to provide for all her household's needs. She applied for a loan of PHP 6,000 from CEVI, which she will use for purchasing farm supplies.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Basilia

texts.en: Mrs. Basilisa J. started preparing her land for planting. She is a rice farmer and has been involved in this business for ten years. It is the only source of income her family has so she makes sure her farm is always productive. She joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She is now applying for a loan of PHP 6,000, which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Martine

texts.fr: Née le 23 Septembre 1976 à Allada dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin, A. Martine vit depuis près de 14 ans à Ahito à Allada. Mariée à APLOGAN Rémi, Martine est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Ahito. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Martine n'a pas été à l'école. Il y a environs 15 ans que Martine mène comme activité, la vente de friperies à Allada. C'est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, que Martine s'approvisionne. Martine a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Martine souhaite agrandir davantage son activité et se faire plus de revenu à la hauteur de ses charges. C'est donc pour renforcer son activité que Martine sollicite un troisième prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born September 23, 1976 in Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic of Benin, Martine A. has lived for the past 14 years in the Ahito neighbourhood of Allada. Married to Rémi APLOGAN, Martine is the mother of two children, both educated. The family lives together in Ahito. The couple share the household expenses. Martine has not attended school. Martine has been selling second-hand clothes in Allada for the past 15 years. She gets her supplies from Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Martine has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, which have been fully reimbursed. Martine wants to expand her activity and increase her earnings to a level consistent with her expenses. It is therefore to bolster her business that Martine is seeking a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy two bales of used clothing

loans.name: Vicitacion

texts.en:
49-year-old Visitacion is happy to share that her one-hectare rice farm has expanded and she thanks God for the additional half hectare of land to till. She and her husband Jose are hand-in-hand in making the farm productive. They both want to give their children proper education so they work hard to achieve it.

Visitacion joined CEVI, a microfinance institution that is a partner of Kiva, to get access to capital assist her in her business venture. She is requesting a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos, which she plans to buy farm supplies such as seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies such as seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.en:
Candelaria has experienced some tough times in her farming. She is 56 years old, married and has four children. She plants rice crops to earn a living. Despite it being tedious, she still finds ways to enjoy farming. She farms so she can provide for her family’s daily needs. 

Candelaria would like to apply for a loan of PHP 6,000. She will use this loan to buy farm supplies to fund her farm.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes is involved in rice farming. She shares that it is really tiring to work at the farm but because she and her husband are together in this, she finds it comforting to know that they both support each other all the time. They have two children whom they want to have a bright future.

Mercedes joined CEVI to have financial assistance for her business. She would like to request a loan of PHP 6,000, which she will use for the farm. She will purchase farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en: Merlinda, 51 years old, has seven children with her husband Rex. She is involved in rice farming. She currently owns 3.5 hectares of rice field, which she and her husband till together. She also raises pigs and chickens to add income to her household. She wants to succeed in business just like any other entrepreneur. She applied for a loan of PHP 6,000 from CEVI in order to purchase seeds, fertilizers, other farm supplies and feed for the chickens and pigs.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina S. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 45 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Rosalina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rosalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 7th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Jeconiah

texts.en:
Jeconiah is a 43-year-old married blacksmith with three children, who all attend school. His wife is a teacher and he has been running his metal fabrications business, where he provides drilling, moulding, and welding services, for two years. He employs three people and his customers are vehicle owners.

With this 40,000 Kenyan shilling loan, he wants to purchase leaf springs and pay for service of his working machines. His other source of income is offering machine rental services. He is grateful to Kiva field partner Faulu Kenya for enabling his business to grow drastically. He hopes to start a large machine workshop someday. Jeconiah describes himself as industrious.

loans.use: To purchase leaf springs and to pay for service of working machines.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en: Jessica M. runs a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling food and daily use products in her community. She is 38 years old, married and has one young child. She is from Opol, Misamis Oriental. Jessica has been in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Jessica joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Jessica has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase products to sell. Jessica is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en:
Teresia is a 49-year-old married woman with six children. She has been renting houses and running her retail shop for twelve years in the Kayole slums of Nairobi.

With the KES 80,000 loan, Teresia wants to increase the stock in her shop. She is grateful to Faulu Kenya for helping her tremendously raise her income and living standard. She hopes to expand her shop and have more rental houses in the future.

Teresia describes herself as successful.

loans.use: To increase the stock of her shop

loans.name: No. 08 Group

texts.en:
Renuka is group leader of this group. She is 35 years old and she has a business doing food production.  She buys food production materials twice a week from the market, then she makes lunch packets.  She can usually sell 10 packets per day.  Now, she needs  20000 LKR to increase the number of items she can sell.  She is married and currently lives with her husband.
 
Another member of this group is Mahatanthila.  She is 41 years old and she has one saL.for increasing beauty in the culture.  She wants to expand her business and create new employment, so she needs 20000 LKR to purchasing more new instruments.

Silva is other member in this group and she is 44 years old.  She is doing a tailoring business.  Right now she has one machine, but she want to buy new machine to develop her business. She needs 20000 LKR to buy a new machine.

Mallika is the fourth member in this group. She is 48 years old and she does business selL. fruits with her husband. Her husband always supports her in the business.  Right now, she does not have enough money to develop her business, so she needs a loan of 20000 LKR.

Maduka is the final member in this group.  She is 38 years old.  Her business is also tailoring and for now she doing her business aL..  She wants to buy a new machine to develop her business.  She needs a loan of 20000 LKR for that purpose.

loans.use: Rice,Vegetable,Fish,Meat and speces purchse

loans.name: Kimya Plus Group

texts.en:
Erméline N. is the leader of a community bank (borrower's group) named "Kimya Plus" which means "Silence" in English. It is composed of 33 members united in solidarity for receiving loans with the goal of developing their businesses.  62 years old, Erméline is a widow and the mother of ten children, whose ages vary between 22 and 43 years old. Only one of her children attends college.

Erméline has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 1971. She runs a general store to the Southwest of Kinshasa in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. She has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills in order to realize her dream of one day opening a larges store.

She would also like to achieve financial independence through her business that now earns her $480 per month. She works to the best of her abilities and uses her contacts so that she might achieve her goals. Erméline is a trustworthy client of HOPE RDC, a Kiva partner microfinance institution, and has  thirteen times obtained and correctly repaid loans.

With this loan, Erméline plans to increase her stock of merchandise by buying cans of food, sacks of rice and sugar and milk and reselling them at a profit.

loans.use: To buy cans of food, sacks of rice and sugar, and milk

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Juncel

texts.en:
Juncel R. is from San Roque, Ozamiz City. He is 30 years old, is single, and has one infant child. Juncel owns and operates a business providing Internet services in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately 30,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Juncel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 45,000 PHP from GDMPC. Juncel is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be his sixth from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Swalehe

texts.en:
Swalehe S. is a married man and an entrepreneur. He runs a clothing shop at Yombo Makangarawe in Temeke district. He purchases his business goods from Kariakoo and Karume secondhand goods city market.

Swalehe has been running the business for seven years and the business income has enabled him to buy a plot of land in Dar es Salaam for house construction, pay school fees, and meet daily family demands and business capitalization needs.

Swalehe needs a loan of TZS 1,400,000 to capitalize his business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Beddy

texts.en:
Beddy C. is from the village of Sibugon, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Beddy owns and operates a general store, selling daily-use products such as salt, sugar, "tuba" (coconut wine), shampoo, biscuits (cookies), noodles, etc., in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Beddy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and to use for processing her business permit. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. Beddy plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell and to process her business permit

loans.name: Bonie

texts.en:
Bonie B. is from the village of Panay Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 33 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Bonie owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over twenty years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Bonie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. Bonie is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be his seventh from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Amugoda

texts.en:
Amugoda has been doing tailoring as business since 2007.  In her business she has two machines and one extra worker.  She wants to develop her business particularly so that she can create new employment.  To do this, she needs a loan of 30000 LKR.  

She dreams of being a mini garment's shop owner in future.

She has two children and living with her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a  new sewing machine and materials to make clothes

loans.name: Islomiddin

texts.en: A. Islomiddin has been working on this farm his entire life. He lives with his wife and three children. Islomiddin relies completely on growing potatoes and processing dried apricots to feed his family, as his lands are only productive for this activity. His children help him with his business. Islomiddin has a large family and that’s why today he wishes to borrow money to buy and process dried apricots. He request 1,000 USD as this amount would help him accomplish his goals in a short time. Your generosity can change his life and that of his family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase dried apricots to process and sell

loans.name: Marcelino

texts.en: Marcelino E.'s main source of income comes from his sari-sari store (general store) selling daily use products such as shampoo, sugar, soy sauce, vinegar, and coffee in his community. He is 64 years old, married and has four adult children. He is from the village of Danlugan, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. Marcelino has been in his business for over five years and earns approximately 1,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Marcelino joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Marcelino is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase products to sell. This will be his first loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue to provide for the basic needs of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Janobiddin

texts.en:
Since Janobiddin was very young he has been part of an agriculture business. He has gained a lot of experience in this business as he has always helped out a lot with the cultivation of crops in his home community of Isfara, Tajikistan. Now he is the father of three adult children. Nowadays Janobiddin has managed to improve his family’s economic situation thanks to the help brought to him by IMON International through a loan that he has used directly for his agricultural business. On this occasion Janobiddin is seeking IMON International’s help so that he can benefit from improved technical assistance in his farming - so that, when harvest time comes around, he can improve his economic situation. Please support this father so his effort is worthwhile. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace A. is an entrepreneur and a married woman. She runs a business of selling maize flour in wholesale to her customers at Yombo Kiwalan in Dar es Salaam. She purchases maize from the wholesale business entrepreneurs and makes it into maize flour which she packs into different sized bags. She sells to wholesalers and retail customers. She has been in the business for five years. The business income helped her to construct her own house, paying school fees for her children and meeting her family's daily demands. She needs a loan of TZS 1,200,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Ilhom

texts.en:
Ilhom I. is married with three children. This is an average size family in Isfara, Tajikistan. However, Ilhom is also a unique entrepreneur. Together with his wife, he has been selling blankets, towels, shawls and other things at the central city market for about 6 years. The secret of his success is simple: not only does he let his customers know the benefits of his products,  he also gives them a sense of relationship which brings them back again and again. However, he doesn’t want to stop where he is at with his venture. Ilhom is seeking a loan of $1000 USD to re-stock the merchandise in his store. We believe that Ilhom’s desire to excel in pleasing his customers will determine his further success and encourage new customers to buy from him.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new supplies of goods to sell.

loans.name: Fozil

texts.en:
N. Fozil is married and has four children who he is very proud of since they are fighting to get ahead. With the faith that his children would go to college to get ahead, he started a business processing and selling dried apricots to be able to make enough money to pay for their schooling. This is why he started this business 20 years ago. He is experienced in this kind of business and that allows him to expand his clientele day by day. Right now Fozil requests $1,000 USD. He is going to spend the loan to purchase dried apricots to process and to sell. With your help, Fozil will be able to feel proud that through much effort, his children went to college and are honorable people.

loans.use: To buy dried apricots

loans.name: Niyoz

texts.en:
N. Niyoz has been dedicated to the activity of agriculture from a young age. He has attended to this activity with great strength. It is necessary to highlight that this gentleman is very involved in his work because he has an obligation to take care of his three children. The need that Niyoz is encountering now is that he doesn't have the financial capital to invest in the crops and for this reason, he applied to IMON International to obtain a loan of $1,000 USD to buy mineral fertilizer in order to prepare his land for the upcoming season. Niyoz promises to repay the loan without any violations and thanks everyone for supporting him.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Zulfa

texts.en:
Zulfa A. is a married woman with four children. One child is in college, one is in secondary school, one in primary school and one is living on his own.

Zulfa is an entrepreneur, running a spare-parts shop that sells different types of car spares at Yombo Buza ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her business goods from wholesale suppliers and sells retail.

Zulfa has been running her business for four years and the business income has helped her to expand her business and meet the daily family needs as well as to pay the school fees for her children.

Zulfa needs a loan of TZS 1,000,000 to buy more spare parts.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts to sell

loans.name: Mohira

texts.en:
Mohira O. is 48 years old. She and her husband raised 4 children. Ten years ago, Mohira learned how to embroider the national skull-cap for men and women, and now she run her own business. She works really hard, getting up very early and going to bed very late, selling the skull-caps at the local market. Mohira dreams of arranging the marriage of her son. With this purpose in mind, Mohira is planning to expand her business. She is requesting a loan of $800 USD. Mohira is planning to spend the loan on purchasing materials for embroidering. Mohira had shown herself to be a reliable client of IMON. Let’s get behind this dedicated mother to make her dream become reality.

loans.use: To purchase materials for embroidering the national skull-cap.

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
Yusuf S. is 49 years old. He and his wife have raised three children. For the past 15 years, Yusuf has been involved in manufacturing wooden doors and window frames. The elder son of Yusuf helps him in the business. Yusuf is respected and known in the neighborhood as a real master, which provides him with lots of clients. The business is stable, generating the main income for the family. Today, Yusuf needs to purchase materials like wood, plywood, flake board and other supplies for his business. Also, he is planning to improve the working conditions of the business. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting $1500 US Dollars. Yusuf thanks all for supporting him and for their trust.

loans.use: To purchase wood, plywood, flake board and other supplies for making furniture.

loans.name: Doto

texts.en: Doto R. H. is an entrepreneurial woman who is married. She runs a grocery store at Kigamboni district in Dar es Salaam. She sells a variety of soft and alcoholic drinks including soda, juice, drinking water, and beer. She purchases the goods from the wholesalers and retail suppliers and sells to the final consumers. She has been in the business for three years and the business income enables her to meet her family's daily demands and business expansion. She plans to expand her business by buying more goods to meet the market demand. She is requesting a loan of TSH 1,000,000 to buy more goods for her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods.

loans.name: Wazaria

texts.fr: Née en 1977 à Kandi, M. Wazaria réside depuis environs 10 ans à Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, où elle vit avec son mari. Mariée à ALLASSANE Razack, un chauffeur, Wazaria est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Mais Wazaria ne vit qu’avec trois de ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Wazaria n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Il y a environs trois ans que Wazaria a commencé la vente de savons et de l’omo à son domicile. Cette activité lui génère des revenus que Wazaria utilise pour aider son mari à assurer les charges de la famille.  Wazaria mène comme activité secondaire, la vente d’igname et de maïs, ce qui lui permet d’avoir d’autres sources de revenus. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Kandi dans le Nord du Bénin, que Wazaria se ravitaille. Wazaria est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a bien remboursé les trois crédits qu’elle avait obtenus auprès de ALIDé. Actuellement Wazaria éprouve de difficultés dans l’approvisionnement de ses produits. C'est la raison pour laquelle Wazaria sollicite un quatrième prêt afin de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle et aussi d’élargir son champ d’activité.
texts.en:
Born in 1977 in Kandi, Wazaria M. has lived for the past 10 years in Lokokoukoumé, in the Sèmè-Podji area, where she lives with her husband. Married to Razack ALLASSANE, a driver, Wazaria is the mother of four children, all educated, of which only three live with her. The couple share family expenses. Wazaria has only attended primary school. About three years ago, Wazaria began selling soap and laundry detergent from her home. She uses the earnings to help her husband with household expenses. Additionally, Wazaria sells yams and corn, which provides her with other sources of income. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and from Kandi in the North of Benin. Wazaria is a former client of ALIDé, and reimbursed in full the three preceding loans she was granted. She is currently experiencing some difficulties in obtaining supplies, which is why she is now requesting a fourth loan from Alidé. This will allow her to satisfy customer demand and broaden her range of activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cartons of toilet soap and laundry detergent.

loans.name: Kayumjon

texts.en: S. Kayumjon is married and has three children. He runs a small business selling rice in the local market and his place is located on the main market aisle where there are many customers every day. He has been in this business for over four years. Kayumjon is a high achiever and a consistent entrepreneur who is very knowledgeable about the market environment. His professional skills and perseverance have helped to ensure rapid growth and success of his business. Kayumjon is requesting a loan for 3,000 Somoni to increase the assortment of his inventory. He is hoping that this loan will help his venture grow and generate extra profits. We believe that Kayumjon's ability to identify tasks critical to business success and then to set up a system for accomplishing them will allow him to continue growing in the sphere of private entrepreneurship.
