She is asking for the amount of 50,000 F CFA so as to have the funds to buy more inventory and take advantage of 'Magal de Touba' (a religious ceremony commemorating the anniversary of the return from exile of Cheikh Ahmadou Bamba, the founder of the Mouride brotherhood which is widespread in Senegal) to sell her wares with ease. She will then restock with the income earned so as to prepare for the 'Maouloud' ('Gamou') in Tivaouane, a religious ceremony which gathers many of the faithful from all over the world to celebrate the birthday of the Prophet Mohamed, Peace and Grace be upon Him.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: add to her budget for restocking her shop

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam N. M. is thirty five years, is married, and has two children who are still schooling.

Mariam’s business is located at Ndunyu Sabuk where for the last year she has been selling shirts and trousers to the local people. Her major challenge has been so many people in that area engaging in the same kind of business as hers and hence customers are spoilt for choice.

However, Mariam is determined to expand her business and become the market leader in this business. She is using her loan to add stock to grow her business. She is a very hardworking and innovative lady.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Shirin

texts.ru: Тагирова Ширин проживает в районе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 50 лет. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Тагирова Ширин торговлей занимается более 12 лет. Она покупает и продает детскую одежду. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Shirin T. lives in the Tursun-zoda district. She is 50 years old, married and has 5 children. Shirin has been involved in retail sales for over 12 years. She buys and sells children's clothing. She is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a hair dryer, tong machine and salon chemicals.

loans.name: Nathan

texts.en:
Nathan is 42 years old, married to Ruth Nduku, and they have three children who go to school. He has been selling household retail goods in Naivasha town for the last three years.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He plans to buy more goods for sale in his retail shop, including dry food stuff (maize flour, sugar).

His future plans are to grow his business and not just sell retail but also wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more food stuff for sale.

loans.name: Dieynaba

texts.fr: Madame Dieynaba G. est une femme de 53 ans très dynamique qui habite a Ouakam a quelques 200 mètres de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC ou elle est sociétaire depuis 9 ans. Elle est spécialisée dans le commerce et la vente d’huile de palme et de produits en provenance de Diaobe ou elle effectue régulièrement des voyages depuis 5 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Elle a déjà rembourse 4 prêts antérieurs qui l’ont aide a garder une stabilité familiale et autonome. Madame G. sollicite un crédit de 200 000 frs dans le but de voyager et d’acheter de l’huile de palme et de la pâte d’arachide en vue de renouveler et d’accroitre son stock de produits qui est destine a la vente. Ses prêts lui ont permis de constater un avancement socio économique non négligeable et de s’assurer une indépendance financière qui lui a donne la force de faire face aux besoins de la maison car son mari est presque inactif.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dieynaba G., 53, is an energetic woman who has been living in Ouakam about 200 meters from the l’U-IMCEC office; she has been a member for 9 years. She is specialized in the buying and selling of palm oil and products coming from Diaobe; she has been making regular trips there for 5 years. She is married and the mother of 8 children. She has already reimbursed four loans which have helped her to have family stability and be independent.

Mrs. G. is requesting a loan in the amount of 200,000 frs with the intention of traveling to buy palm oil and peanut butter so as to update and add to her stock of products to be sold. Her loans have allowed her to make appreciable socio-economic progress and ensure her financial independence which makes it possible for her to deal with family needs, her husband being more or less idle.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: adding to her working capital

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema S. is a married woman and a small-business owner. She runs a business as a food vender at Tua Moyo, Kigambon, Dar es Salaam.

Rehema prepares and sells both cooked and fried food. She sells cooked rice, fried fish, roast meat and bites (bread-like rolls) to her customers and has been in the business for six years.

From her business income, Rehema has managed to build a house, capitalize the business, and also meets her family’s daily needs. She plans to diversify the business by opening a foodstuffs shop but funds are a most limiting factor.

Rehema needs a loan of TZS 1,200,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Balongi Plus Group

texts.en:
Nelly Bonjeka M. is the manager of the group “Balongi Plus” made up of 29 members firmly united to receive loans from the MFI (micro-finance institution) HOPE DRC in order to develop their businesses.

She is 40 years old, is married, and has three children who go to school.

Nelly’s main business is selling vegetables and sausages in her area. She has been a micro-entrepreneur since 1985 and each week, her business brings in a profit of $90. She likes her business and she is working hard to achieve her goal of one day opening a general store.

Nelly is a loyal client of HOPE DRC and has already received eight different loans and has repaid them properly. She intends to use this next loan to buy 10 kilograms of sausages to resell with the aim of increasing her profits.

loans.use: To purchase 10 kgs of sausages to resell at a profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth M. is a 44 year old widow with no children.  She has been operating her green grocery shop in Ndabibi which is on the outskirts of Naivasha town for the last three years.

Ruth was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her second loan.  She plans to buy more variety of goods for sale like oranges, pawpaw,(a large edible berry), pineapple and mangoes which are in season.

Ruth plans to expand her business and also run a fruit salad shop on the side in the near future.

loans.use: Buy more fruits for sell.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses M. N. is a 41 year old married butcher with three children all of whom are all attending school. He has been running his butchery for five years and employs one person. Previously, he worked at a shop and sold clothes. With a 30,000 Kes loan, Moses wants to expand the butchery and purchase a charger for batteries. He is grateful to Faulu for helping him grow his business. In the future, he hopes to become a matatu (shared taxi) operator and further improve the standard of living for his family. Moses describes himself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To expand the butchery and buy acharger for batteries.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet K. is 48 years of age, married with four children ages 10 to 23 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in a five room house. Harriet takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home.  Harriet's greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for children and medication. 

Harriet sells  school uniforms in Nalukolongo  to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. She serves about five customers a day. She has been in this business for over fifteen years. Her main challenges are transportation and seasonality. When its school holidays no one buys uniforms.  Harriet sells all types of uniform clothing including sweaters and  t.shirts. She sells both retail and wholesale. 

Harriet has been with MCDT for six years servicing her twelfth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more rolls of uniform material and yarn for sweater knitting. Harriet hopes to see her business grow and to start employing people to help her.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials and yarn for sweeter knitting

loans.name: Godwin

texts.en: Godwin T. is a married entrepreneur. He runs a foodstuffs and fruits shop at Buguruni Matumbi in Dar es Salaam. Godwin purchases his goods wholesale from the city market shops. He has been in the business for four years and the business income generated is used to meet his family's needs and to capitalize his business. Godwin is asking for a loan of  1,200,000 TZS to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Armik

texts.en:
Armik A. was born in 1954 in Manashid village, Azerbaijan. He is married and has a son and a daughter. Now, Armik lives in Aghavnadzor village in the Ijevan area with his wife, son and daughter-in-law. His daughter is married and lives with her husband in Vardenis city.

Before, Armik worked as a brigadier for about four years, deputy village head for about three years, and eight years as a milkman. Since 2000, he and his son have been engaged in farming (stock-breeding, bee-keeping and market gardening) on their private land in Aghavnavanq village. With profit from farming, Armik has provided all of his family’s needs.

Armik needs a 400,000 AMD loan to buy fodder for his farm animals and to repair the roof of his cattle-shed.

loans.use: To buy fodder for his farm animals and to repair the roof of his cattle-shed

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en: Georgina M. is a married woman.  She runs a shop selling a variety of goods at Buguruni Kisiwani in Dar es Salaam. Business goods sold include; soap, maize flower, maize, beans, cooking oil and rice. She purchases the business goods from the city market wholesale and retail shops. Georgina has been running the business for four years and the business income generated is used to meet her family's needs and  to capitalize her business. Georgina is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 TZS to buy more business goods and to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Mussa

texts.en: Mussa M. is a married man, with five children who are already working and self-sufficient. He runs a kiosk at Tandika ward in Dar es Salaam.  He sells a variety of goods at his kiosk, which he purchases from wholesale and retail shops at Tandika city market. He has had his business for five years. His income helps him to meet his daily needs and business expenses.  He is requesting a loan of 800,000 Tanzanian Shillings (TZS) to buy more business goods.

loans.use: to purchase more business goods

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 42 years of age.  She is married with six children aged 5-22 years. All her children go to school. Beatrice resides in and owns a five-roomed house where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family eats three meals a day, and has access to electricity, but not to piped water at home.  Her greatest monthly expenses includes paying utility bills, school fees for her children and medication.  

Beatrice is a poultry farmer in Makerere, where she rears both broiler and layer chickens. She picks at least 4 trays of eggs a day and sells them, retail and wholesale, to all kinds of people. She works seven days a week, serving about 10 customers a day. She has had her business for over fifteen years.  Her main challenges are transportation of chicken feed and thieves. Besides her poultry business, she also has some pigs around her place.  

Beatrice has been with MCDT for two years, and has taken four loans, working the whole time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more chicken feed and chicks. She hopes to see her business grow bigger, and to start getting 20 trays a day.

loans.use: to buy chicken feed and chicks

loans.name: Shamsiddin

texts.ru: Азимов Шамсиддин проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 38 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Азимов Шамсиддин торговлей занимается более 4 лет. Он покупает и продает сельско- хозяйственные продукты. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Shamsiddin A. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 38 years old, married and has 3 children. Shamsiddin has been involved in retail sales for over 4 years. He buys and sells agricultural products. He is requesting this loan in order to increase product turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sophie

texts.fr:
Madame Sophie D. est une dame de 46 ans qui a adhéré a la caisse de l’U-IMCEC de Ouakam il y’a un an. Elle a déjà bénéficie de deux prêts antérieurs. Elle est mariée et mère de 6 enfants.
Pendant la période de chaleur madame D. s’adonne a la vente de glace et de jus et ceci depuis 1982. Elle vend aussi devant chez elle ou a l’école qui se trouve non loin de chez elle des fruits saisonniers pour enfants tels que les oranges, des bonbons, des biscuits et divers autres. C’est l’évolution de son commerce de jus qui l’a beaucoup motive a vouloir progresser dans son activité commerciale. Ainsi elle sollicite un crédit de 250 000 frs pour acheter un stock de produits qui va lui faciliter la préparation de petit déjeuner .Les différents prêts qui lui ont permis d’augmenter son capital ont été pour elle l’occasion d’accroitre ses revenus et d’acquérir de nouveaux matériels et en même temps d’équiper petit a petit sa maison.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sophie D., 46, has been a member of U-IMCEC Ouakam for one year. She has already received two loans. She is married and the mother of 6 children.

During the hot season, Mrs. D. sells ice and juice, something she has been doing since 1982. She also sells, in front of her house or at the school located near her, seasonal fruit for children such as oranges, as well as candy, cookies, and various other items. The evolution of her juice business is really motivating her to expand her enterprise. Thus, she is requesting a loan of 250,000 frs to buy a stock of ingredients that will let her prepare breakfasts. The previous loans that have allowed her to grow her working capital have led to increased income and permitted her to acquire new materials as well as equipping her house, little by little.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: adding to her working capital

loans.name: Anatalia

texts.en: Anatalia E. is a married Tanzanian woman. She runs a business selling charcoal in Kiwalani, Dar es Salaam. Charcoal is the main source of domestic power in this developing country due to the high price and instability of electrical power. She purchases the charcoal from wholesale suppliers and sells it to retail customers for domestic consumption. She managed to buy a plot of land in Dar es Salaam, and meets her family’s daily needs from the income generated by her business. She needs a loan of 1,500,000 Tanzanian Shillings (TZX) to diversify the business.

loans.use: to diversify her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Tub-making materials and instruments

loans.name: Tillo

texts.ru: Садуллоев Тилло проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 41 год. Женат, имеет 7 детей. Садуллоев Тилло имеет среднее Техническое образование по специальности "Шофер". В области растениеводства работает более 10 лет. Он сажает пщеницу. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Tillo S. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 41 years old, married and has 7 children. Tillo has a secondary technical education as a driver. He has been working in the agricultural field for over 10 years. He plants wheat. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is 49, married, and has six children aged 4-24 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a five-roomed house where Edith stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity, but not to piped water at home.  They have three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses includes paying utility bills, school fees for her children, and medication. 

Edith sells charcoal in Kikoni to all kinds of people. She works seven days a week, serving an average of 30 customers a day. She has had her business for over fifteen years.  Her main challenges are transportation of chicken feed and thieves.  She sells both on retail and wholesale. She has been with MCDT for two years, and has taken four loans, working the whole time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She hopes to see her business grow bigger, and to start selling on wholesale only.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 36, married, and has six children aged 4-10 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a five-roomed house where Margaret stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity, but not to piped water at home.  They have three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for her children, and medication.  

Margaret owns a stall selling second hand clothes in Kitawuluzi. She works seven days a week, serving an average of 10 customers a day. She has had her business for over fifteen years. Her main challenges are transportation of used clothes and defaulters. She sells both on retail and wholesale. She has been with MCDT for six years, and has taken fourteen loans, working the whole time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes. She hopes to see her business grow bigger, and to start importing clothes herself.

loans.use: to buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Mireya Lourdes

texts.es:
Mireya L. de 38 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento pero solo cuenta con luz como servicio básico, su esposo es maestro de contabilidad con el tiene 4 hijos de 18,16, 12 y 6 años de edad.

Mireya comenzó haciendo un estudio de mercado en el sector de donde vivía, al momento de darse cuenta que una papelería era rentable empezó con cuadernos, plumas, hojas.

Ahora Mireya trabaja desde las 07h00 hasta las 21h00 todos los días, vende un aproximado mensual de 3 pacas de cuadernos, 100 láminas, 20 cajas de lápices, plumas, marcadores etc. Una las dificultades que tiene son los racionamientos de energía del gobierno.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar cuadernos, laminas, lápices y otros suministros para agrandar el negocio. En el futuro quiere ampliar su negocio y poner sucursales de su negocio.
texts.en:
Mireya L., 38, lives on the outskirts of the Ecuadorean city of Guayaquil. Her house is made of cement but she only has a rudimentary electric service. Her husband teaches accounting and they have 4 children, 18-, 16-, 12- and 6-years old.

Before Mireya started her business, she studied the market in her neighborhood and realized that a business supplying products such as notebooks, pens and paper was profitable.

Mireya now works every day from 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m., selling around 3 packs of notebooks; 20 boxes of pencils, pens, paper, markers, etc per month. One of the difficulties she facies is government energy rationing.

Mireya will use the loan to buy notebooks, paper, pencils and other supplies that will help her to grow her business. In the future, she hopes to expand the business and open additional stores.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: In Jesus Name Group

texts.en:
Victoria T., the leader of a group of five borrowers called In Jesus Name, is a 53-year-old widow with four children aged 14 -23 years whose educational levels are 5th – 11th grade. She also cares for a nephew.  Victoria and her family live in the Pipeline community but work in the Red-Light market, the largest market in Paynesville near Monrovia, Liberia. She could not continue her education through 9th grade due to poverty.

Victoria’s business is the sale of quality charcoal by the bag, an enterprise she started with 2000.00 Liberian Dollars as her working capital given to her by her brother. She buys her product from rural Liberia, bringing it to town to be sold in the Red-Light market, the largest market in Liberia. Having operated this business for four years now, she hopes to expand it in the near future. Victoria needs this loan to purchase more charcoal for resale to improve her business, and she dreams of giving her children better education.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Victoria is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal for resale to improve her business.

loans.name: Mercedes Cecilia

texts.es:
La sra. Mercedes Cecilia O. A. de 39 años de edad tiene dos hijos y vive en Psje Los Angeles – Cercado de Ica.
La solicitante trabaja en la venta diaria de causa, papa rellena y otros en su mismo domicilio trabaja en este rubro desde hace 2 años y medios su  negocio lo inicio con la venta de chicha morada y sandwich antes ella trabajaba en el campo pero luego empezo con su propio negocio.
Solicita el financiamiento para comprar un toldo para cubrirse del sol y tambien para algunos gastos personales. 
Ella goza de buenas referncias de parte de los vecinos y de los comensales que diariamente la visitana.
texts.en:
Mercedes Cecilia O. A. is 39 years old, has two children and lives on Los Angeles street in the Ica district. She works selling causa (a Peruvian dish), papa rellena (a dish like a twice baked potato) and other food out of her home. She has been in this business for two and a half years; she started by selling chica morada (a local drink) and sandwiches. She used to work in the fields but decided to start her own business. She is seeking a loan in order to buy a canopy to create shade for the business and also for some personal expenses. She receives great referrals from her neighbors and her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in her business

loans.name: Rufine Biowa

texts.fr: Z. Rufine Biowa est née le 14 Juin 1968 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a une dizaine d’année que Rufine Biowa s’est installée à PK 10 Marina, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Mariée à TOSSOU Célestin, Rufine Biowa est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais quatre des enfants sont à sa charge et vivent ensemble avec son mari et elle. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Rufine Biowa n’a pas été à l’école. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Rufine Biowa mène comme activité, la vente de divers produits (pâtes alimentaires, sucre, lait, sardine, conserves de tomate, biscuits, huile, etc.) à son domicile. Rufine Biowa vend également des céréales (riz, etc.), ce qui lui permet d’avoir plusieurs sources de revenus. Il y a près de 7 ans que Rufine Biowa exerce cette activité. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Rufine Biowa se ravitaille. Rufine Biowa a bien remboursé les crédits qu’elle avait obtenus de ALIDé. Rufine Biowa souhaite augmenter davantage le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre aux différents besoins de ses clients. Cependant, Rufine Biowa ne réunit pas assez de fonds pour renforcer son activité. C’est pourquoi Rufine Biowa sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un autre crédit.
texts.en:
Z. Rufine Biowa was born on June 14, 1968 in Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. Rufine Biowa settled ten years ago in PK10 Marina, in the community of Sèmè-Podji. Married to TOSSOU Célestin, Rufine Biowa is the mother of five children, all in school. Four of the children are supported by and live with her and her husband. The couple supports the family together. In order to pay her various expenses, Rufine Biowa runs a business selling diverse products (pasta, sugar, milk, sardines, canned tomatoes, cookies, oil, etc.) from her home. She also sells grain (rice, etc.), which allows her to have several income sources. Rufine Biowa has been in this business for seven years. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, international market of Benin. Rufine Biowa has fully repaid the loans she has received from ALIDé. Rufine Biowa would like to increase her stock of products and better respond to her customers' different needs. However, she does not have enough capital to build up her business. That is why Rufine Biowa is seeking another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pasta, sardines, milk, sugar, peanut oil, and rice

loans.name: Let God Be Group

texts.en: Tenneh K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Let God Be. She is 39 years old and a single mother with three children between the ages of 6 and 16 years old. Their educational levels range from nursery to ninth grade. Tenneh and her family live and work in Saye Town, a community that has both poor and middle-class Liberians, in Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. She was never able to go to school herself due to lack of financial support from her parents. Tenneh’s business is the sale of general goods such as rice, oil and other cooking ingredients. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail to residents of Saye Town. She has been running this business for nine years and is hoping to own a shop in the near future. Tenneh started selling with 4,000 Liberian Dollars but now operates with about 10,000 Liberian Dollars. She communicates with her customers in a good manner and sells good products in order to encourage customers to continue buying from her. Tenneh needs this loan to purchase rice, oil, seasoning, etc., for resale. She dreams of being a good provider to her family and well-known as a businesswoman. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Tenneh is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women. Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today!

loans.use: To purchase rice, oil, seasonings, etc., for resale

loans.name: Jose Antonio

texts.es:
El Sr. P. C. Jose Antonio de 26 años de edad vive con su conviviente desde hace 6 años con la cual tiene un hijo menor de edad el cual asiste al colegio de la zona ellos viven en el Pueblo joven Sr. De Luren – Ica.
El Sr. Se dedica desde hace 7 años al transporte antes trabajaba en vehiculos alquilados pero actualmente cuenta con su unidad de transporte propia en el cual taxea diariamente tambien realiza viajes a otras ciudades como Nazca – Pisco - Chincha él realiza esta actividad de lunes a sábado de 6:30 am hasta las 2:00 pm y de 4.00 pm hasta las 10.00 pm.
El y su esposa son unas personas bien responsables ya que desean mas adelante tener su casa propia  para asi darle una mejor estabilidad a su hijo.
Los sres solicitan el credito para poder cambiar los asientos al carro y tambien para algunos gastos personales. 
Ellos son bien responsable gozan de buenas referencias de parte de los vecinos quienes manifiestan que son bien trabajadores y unos buenos vecinos.
texts.en:
P. C. Jose Antonio is 26 years old and has lived with his girlfriend for 6 years; they have one young son who attends the local school. They live in the Sr. de Luren development in Ica. For the past 7 years he has worked in transportation as a taxi driver; before he rented the taxis he used but now he has his own vehicle. Besides taxiing within the city, he also does trips to other cities like Nazca, Pisco and Chinca. He works Monday to Saturday from 6:30 am to 2:00 pm and from 4:00 pm to 10:00 pm. He and his partner are very responsible people who would like to eventually own their own home to give greater stability to their son. They are requesting a loan in order to get new seats for the car and for some personal expenses. They are the beneficiaries of great referrals from their neighbors who know them to be very responsible and hard-working.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in his vehicle

loans.name: Suzanne

texts.fr: H. Suzanne est née en 1951 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Suzanne habite au quartier Finagnon à Cotonou, depuis 39 ans environs. Mariée à TOHOUNKPIN Célestin, un policier à la retraite, Suzanne est mère de six enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Parmi les enfants, cinq restent encore à la charge de Suzanne et vivent donc avec Suzanne et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Suzanne n’a pas été à l’école. Pour assurer les différentes charges qui lui incombent, Suzanne mène comme activité, la vente d’igname et de beignets frits (fait à base de haricot) à Abattoir à Cotonou. Suzanne s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marhé international du Bénin. Il y a près de 39 ans que Suzanne mène cette activité. Suzanne est une bonne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. La clientèle de Suzanne s’agrandit de jour en jour et elle n’arrive plus à bien répondre à la demande de tous ses clients. En vue de renforcer son capital et d’élever le niveau de son activité, Suzanne sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
H. Suzanne was born in 1951 in Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. Suzanne has lived in the Finagnon neighborhood of Cotonou for about 39 years. Married to TOHOUNKPIN Célestin, a retired police officer, Suzanne is the mother of six children who are all in school. Among the children, five are still in the care of Suzanne and thus live with her and her husband. The couple jointly ensures that the family expenses are paid. Suzanne did not go to school. In order to pay her different expenses, she runs a business selling yams and fritters (made from beans) in Abattoir in Cotonou. Suzanne gets her supplies in Dantokpa, international market of Benin. She has been in this business almost 39 years. Suzanne is a good client of ALIDé who fully repays her loans. Suzanne's clientele grows from day to day, and she is no longer able to fully meet the demand of all her customers. Looking to increase her working capital and raise the level of her business, Suzanne is seeking another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of yams, beans, and peanut oil

loans.name: Leandro

texts.es:
Leandro tiene 36 años de edad, es conviviente hace 4 años, tiene un hijo de 2 años de 
edad. El vive en casa de sus suegros con su familia, El adquirió la mototaxi con las 
utilidades ya que el se dedicaba a la minería informal, en la parte de la sierra. El 
viene brindando este servicio ya hace un año y medio. Ellos emigraron de su ciudad natal,
para poder brindarle mejores condiciones de vida para su hijo. Leandro  y su cónyuge 
sueñan con tener su casa propia ya que por el momento los están ayudando brindandole un espacio en casa de sus suegros, Leandro destina todos los ingresos que obtiene a la manutención de su familia. 
Leandro solicita el crédito para realizar el mantenimiento de su mototaxi y así no tener problemas con su vehiculo.
texts.en:
Leandro is 36 years old and has lived with his girlfriend for 4 years with whom he has a 2 year old son. They live in his in-laws' home. He was able to save up to purchase a moto-taxi with money he earned working in mining in the mountainous region of Peru. He has worked as a moto-taxi driver for the past year and a half. They emigrated from the city of their birth to provide a better life for their son. Leandro and his partner dream of owning their own home since now they are living with his in-laws. Leandro uses all of his income to support his family. He is seeking a loan for moto-taxi maintenance in order to avoid problems with his vehicle.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle maintenance

loans.name: Martine

texts.fr: A. Martine est née en 1950 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à Julien, un chauffeur, Martine est mère de six enfants, dont deux sont encore à sa charge. Seulement certains de ses enfants sont scolarisés. Martine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari dans la zone des Ambassade à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C’est depuis neuf ans que Martine et son mari se sont installés dans ce quartier. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Martine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Martine vend à son domicile divers produits (savons, lait, allumettes, sucre, insecticides, galettes d’arachide, etc.). Martine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Il y a près de cinq ans que Martine mène cette activité. C’est une bonne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Martine sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé, dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux faire face à la demande des clients.
texts.en:
A. Martine was born in 1950 in Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Benin. Married to Julien, a driver, she is the mother of six children, two of whom are still in her care. Only some of her children are in school. Martine lives with her children and husband in the Ambassade zone of Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. Martine and her husband settled in this neighborhood about nine years ago. The couple jointly ensures that the family expenses are paid. Martine did not go to school. In order to pay her different expenses, she sells various products from her home (soap, milk, matches, sugar, pesticides, peanut cakes, etc.). She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, international market of Benin. Martine has been in this business almost five years. She is a good client of ALIDé who fully repays her loans. Martine is seeking another loan from ALIDé, with the goal of building up her business and better meeting the demand of her customers.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of soap, sugar, milk, and peanut cakes

loans.name: Costa

texts.en:
Costa is 43 years of age and married with seven children between the ages of 4 and 17. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a five-roomed house, where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses includes paying utility bills, school fees for her children and medication.

Costa owns a stall selling all types of snacks, ranging from samosas chapatti to pancakes. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 30 customers a day. She has done this business for over 10 years. Her main challenges are transportation of baking flour and an inadequate market for eatables plus defaulters. She sells both on a retail and wholesale basis. She has been with MCDT for nine years, servicing her 20th loan and working all this long with the same group mates. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more cartons of baking flour, cooking oil and cowpeas for samosas, plus bunches of yellow bananas for pancakes. She is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to own a bigger bakery.
.

loans.use: To buy cartons of baking flour, jerrycans of cooking oil, cowpeas for samosas and bunches of bananas for pancakes

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.fr: Née en 1962 à Avrankou dans le département de l’Ouémé, D. Rosalie vit depuis une quinzaine d’année dans la zone des Ambassades à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à SALAKO Houdjinou un chauffeur, Rosalie est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple vit avec leurs trois enfants et participe ensemble aux diverses charges de la famille. Rosalie n’a jamais fréquenté mais exerce comme activité la vente de haricot préparé et du pain. Rosalie possède à son actif, 4 années d’expériences dans l’exercice de cette activité. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Rosalie se ravitaille. Rosalie vend ses produits dans son quartier. Rosalie a bénéficié par le passé de cinq crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Faute de moyen financiers pour diversifier et renforcer ses activités, Rosalie souhaite bénéficier d’un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1962 at Avrankou in the Oueme district, D. Rosalie has been living in the embassies area in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for about 15 years. Married to Salako Houdjinou, a driver, Rosalie is the mother of three children, all in school. The couple live with their three children and contribute together to the various expenses of the family. Rosalie has never been to school, but sells ready made ( canned) beans and bread as a business. Rosalie has in her advantage 4 years of experience in the operation of this business. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She sells her products in her neighborhood. Rosalie benefitted from 5 loans from ALIDe in the past and repaid all loans. For lack of funds to diversify and strengthen her business, Rosalie hopes to benefit from a sixth loan from ALIDe.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of beans, bread, peanut oil, and gari

loans.name: Five Sisters Group

texts.en: Beatrice W. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Five Sisters. She is 42 years old and married with two children, aged 14 and 17. One of her children is in the 3rd grade, but the other child has a problem with his hand and because of that, he is unable to write. Beatrice and her family live around the Red Light community. She works in the Red Light market, the largest market in Liberia, which is located in Paynesville on the outskirts of the capital, Monrovia. Beatrice could not continue her education past the 7th grade due to the Liberian civil war. Beatrice's business is the sale of plantains, bananas, yams, limes, etc. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail on a table at the Red Light Market. She has been running this business for 13 years and hopes to get into the general-store business in the near future. Beatrice started selling her general goods with 1,000 Liberian Dollars as working capital from her own savings. She got into it as a beginner. She talks to her customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Beatrice needs this loan to purchase more plantains, bananas and yams for resale. She dreams of being able to give her sick son good medical care so that he can be able to go to school. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Beatrice is the one holding the sign. Ahmed K. is in the inset photo at lower right. Despite the group's name, Five Sisters, there is one male member, Ahmed. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women. Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today!

loans.use: To purchase more plantains, bananas and yams for resale to improve her business

loans.name: Latifath

texts.fr: M. Latifath est née le 26 Septembre 1970 à Niamey au Niger, pays voisin du Bénin. Mariée à BELLO Gafari un commerçant, Latifath est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille s’est installée depuis environs 3 ans au quartier Agbalilamè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la maison. Latifath n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Latifath mène comme activité la vente de divers produits (savons de lessive et de toilette, sucre, œufs, conserves, pâtes alimentaires, amuses gueule, biscuits, bombons, lait, farine de manioc, etc.) au parc MIVVO  à Sèmè-Podji. Latifath vend également de l’huile de palme er du thé, ce qui lui permet de multiplier ses sources de revenus. Latifath s’approvisionne auprès des distributeurs à Cotonou. Latifath a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. La clientèle de Latifath s’accroît au jour le jour ; mais Latifath n’arrive plus à bien la satisfaire parce que les moyens financiers dont elle dispose sont faibles. Latifath sollicite donc un deuxième crédit pour renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
M. Latifath was born on September 26, 1970 in Niamey in Niger, a neighboring country of Bénin. Married to BELLO Gafari, a shopkeeper, Latifath is the mother of three children, all enrolled in school. The family has been living for about three years in the Agbalilamè neighborhood of Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin. The couple share in supporting the family.

Latifath did not go to school. In order to cover her various expenses, Latifath sells various products (detergent and toilet soap, sugar, eggs, tinned goods, pasta, snacks, cookies, candy, milk, manioc flour, etc.) in the MIVVO truck stop in Sèmè-Podji. Latifath also sells palm oil and tea, which allows her to increase her sources of income.

Latifath buys her goods from distributors in Cotonou. She has already received one loan from ALIDé and reimbursed it in a timely manner. Her clientele is ever growing, but Latifath is not able to satisfy them all since the financial means at her disposal are insufficient. Therefore, she is requesting a second loan to bolster her little business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of soap, sugar, trays of eggs, and tinned goods

loans.name: Humberto Javier

texts.es:
El Sr. L. Zuñiga Humberto Javier de 40 años de edad vive en casa de su madre él es soltero no tiene hijos por eso apoya a su madre en los gastos de la casa viven en San Miguel – Cercado de Ica.
El Sr. Se dedica desde hace 8 años al transporte antes trabajaba alquilando mototaxi pero actualmente cuneta con su unidad de transorte propia lo que le permite un mejor ingreso trabaja de lunes a domingo de 6:30 am hasta las 3:00 y de 4.30 ha 10.0pm.
El sr es bien responsable con su madre quien confia mucho en él  por que poco a poco ha logrado obtener sus bienes.
El goza de buenas referencias de parte de los vecinos solicita el financiamiento para poder mejorar su unidad de trabajo ya que esta fallando un poco el motor.
Su sueño es poder lograr comprarse otras unidades y darlas a trabajar y asi él poder  iniciar un negocio que es lo que tiene proyectado.
texts.en:
L. Zuñiga Humberto Javier is 40 years old and lives in his mother's house. He is single and has no children but supports his mother with household expenses; they live in San Miguel in the province of Ica. For the past 8 years he has worked in transportation as a taxi driver; he used to rent a motorcycle taxi but now he has his own vehicle which provides him with a better income. He works from Monday to Sunday from 6:30 am to 3:00 pm and from 4:30 pm to 10:00 pm. He is very responsible as he takes care of his mother who depends on him as he has helped to provide for her over the years. He has received many good referrals from his neighbors. He is seeking a loan in order to fix his vehicle which is having some problems. His dream is to eventually purchases other vehicles that he can put to work in order to start his own business.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in vehicle

loans.name: Erika Roxana

texts.es:
Erika tiene 39 años de edad, es soltera, vive en casa de sus padres y hermanas. 
Ella es propietaria de una bodega ubicada en una zona rural de la ciudad de Ica, inicio el 
negocio aproximadamente hace 5 años, inicio con un capital pequeño producto de ahorros 
obtenidos, en la actualidad su capital se ha ido incrementando  con mucho esfuerzo fruto de su trabajo. Ella actualmente atiende el negocio de manera calida y amable ya que la gran mayoría 
de sus clientes son personas que laboran en los fundos ubicados en los alrededores de su bodega. 
Erika sueña con tener su casa propia, pero por el momento se hace cargo de sus padres 
los cuales ya son de edad avanzada. Ella quisiera brindarles los cuidados y atenciones 
debidos, pero los ingresos que obtiene, no le permite asumir estos gastos, por este 
motivo es que solicita el crédito para incrementar su mercadería y asi poder tener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Erika is 39 years old, single, and lives with her parents and sisters. She runs a small store in a rural area of the city of Ica; she started the business 5 years ago with a small amount of capital from her savings. Her capital has increased due to the fruits of her hard work. She attends to her customers with a great degree of service and friendliness; the majority of her customers work on the large farms close to her store. Erika dreams of owning her own home, but now she takes care of her parents who are elderly. She would like to take better care of them but her income is insufficient to provide everything she would like for them. This loan will be used to increase her inventory and help her improve her income.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of traditional articles, wholesale

loans.name: Yuri Elena

texts.es: La señora Yuri tiene negocio de ventas de pinturas varias, ella va a utilizar el crédito para invertirlo en el mismo y así poder incrementar sus ventas y dar una mejor atención a sus clientes esto con el fin de tener una mayor ganancia, el negocio lo empezó el papa con capital propio y desde hace ya mas de tres años doña Yuri esta al frente de la administración del mismo ella es soltera y estudia  además ayuda a su familia en el sustento de la misma  también a su abuelita que vive con ellos, desde tempranas horas abren el negocio en donde se mantienen en constante movimiento ya que también les hacen pedidos de materiales los cuales ellos se encargan de llevarlos a los talleres con los que trabajan.
texts.en:
Yuri’s business is selling different paints. She will use the loan to invest in her business. That way she will be able to increase her sales and give her customers better service. In the end, she will have greater earnings. Her father started the business with his own money over three years ago. Yuri is in charge of the administration of the business. She is single, and she goes to school. She also helps support her family, which includes her grandmother who lives with them. They open the business very early, and they are in constant motion. They also take orders for materials that they deliver to the shops they work with.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for her business

loans.name: *donata

texts.en: *Donata O. is an entrepreneur and a married woman. She runs a business keeping poultry at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. She keeps both layers and broilers in her four poultry cages. She constructed four poultry cages, two for broilers and two for layers. She has been in the business for four years and the business income generated from selling eggs and broilers helped her to expand the business by constructing poultry cages. It also helped her meet her daily family demands. She needs a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to increase business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Miria

texts.en:
Miria is 45 years old and married with six children between the ages of 5 and 17 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a three-room house where she stays with four people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include utility bills, school fees for her children and medication. Miria sells chicken in Bwaise market. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day. She sells both broilers and layers.  She has done this business for over 10. Her main challenge is transporting the chicken from the farmers to her place of business.  She sells at both retail and wholesale. She has been with MCDT for nine years, servicing her 18th loan working all along with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more chickens for resale. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to start rearing her own chickens.
.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase printed cloth

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna T. is an entrepreneur and a married woman.  She runs a grocery store at Chanika ward in Dar es Salaam. She sells a variety of goods at her grocery including foodstuffs, soft drinks and other home utterances. She purchases the goods from wholesale and retail shops in the city market shopping center. She plans to expand her business but funds are the limiting factor. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 500,000 to buy more goods.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of pagnes (traditional clothing)

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce J. is a married entrepreneur and businesswoman. She runs a business as a food vender at Tungi  Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. She sells a variety of cooked and fried foods to customers. Business goods are purchased from the city market and the retail shops. Her business plan is to open up and run a café. She needs a loan of Tshs 400,000 to inprove her business. 10609

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 29 years of age and married with four children between the ages of 8 and 14 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a three-room house where she stays with five people. She doesn’t take care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include utility bills, school fees for her children and medication. Rose is a tailor in Bwaise market, sewing all types of clothes including Gomesi (African tunics), shirts and dresses. She also repairs torn clothing.  She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day. She has done this business for over 10 years. Her main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season because she works from an open place.  She sells at both retail and wholesale. She has been with MCDT for seven years, servicing her 14th loan and working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more clothing materials and threads. She hopes to see her business grow bigger, to start a tailoring school and to start sewing bridal gowns
.

loans.use: To buy more material and thread for sewing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of jewelry

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en:
Gorret is 26 years of age and married with four children between the ages of 8 and 14 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a three-room house where she stays with five people. She doesn’t take care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include utility bills, school fees for her children and medication. Gorret owns a stall in Mengo Mackay selling bananas and tomatoes.  She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day. She has done this business for over 10 years. Her main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season because she works from an open place.  She sells at both retail and wholesale. She has been with MCDT for four years, servicing her seventh loan, working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas and boxes of tomatoes. She is hoping to see her business grow bigger and to start selling at wholesale only.
.

loans.use: To buy more bananas and tomatoes

loans.name: Monika

texts.en:
Monika is married with two children. She sells bed sheets at Beregovo market. She has been in this business for five years. Her monthly income is about 5,500 UAH; her working capital is 15,000 UAH.

Monika likes her business because it does not change with the seasons. People always purchase bed sheets, most often as a gift. Monika would like to increase her assortment to attract more clients. She is requesting a loan of 6,500 UAH. Monika would like to develop her business further so that she can increase her income and take better care of her family.

loans.use: To increase her assortment of products

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander is married and has two children. He works at the local market selling slippers and seeds. Alexander has been in this business for six years. He considers himself to be a successful entrepreneur. First of all, his kiosk is located at a good place in the market. Second, but not least, his products are good quality and he gives good customer service. Many people come back to Alexander and become repeat clients.
Alexander would like to borrow 12,000 UAH to purchase more seeds in view of the upcoming spring season. He hopes to receive additional income and spend it on his family.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Les Samants Group

texts.en:
The “Les Samants” group is made up of 15 male and female entrepreneurs. After successfully repaying their first loan, they are looking forward to continued success and growth in their businesses with their second loan. Though small, the group has a wide range of businesses. Rosemaine M. is one of three representatives of the group. She is married with eight children ranging from 1.5 to 25 years old.
The hardworking mom mostly sells candies, cookies, and other little snacks in bulk to other local merchants but also sells small amounts to her students at school where she works with her husband. She says that the first loan was beneficial to her business because she was able to create savings and support her older children who are studying in the big city. She recognizes that she may have a difficult road ahead of her because her suppliers were based out of Port Au Prince, which was recently struck by a major earthquake. Despite that, she is still hopeful for her future.  On behalf of Rosemaine, Les Samants, and Esperanza, we thank you for your support.

loans.use: To buy snacks in bulk quantities

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en: Mwajuma K. is a married small-business woman. She runs a business selling fried and fresh fish at Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the fish direct from the fishermen at Kigamboni Ferry fish market center. She has been in the business for three years. She needs a loan of Tshs 500,000 to buy more fish to meet her customer's demands.

loans.use: To buy more fish

loans.name: Women Of Vision Group

texts.en: Vagular M. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Women of Vision. She said she was born the year the first road was built in her home town, Voinjama City in Lofa County, northern Liberia. Vagular is divorced, with four children 17 to 47 years old with educational levels of 8th grade through high school graduate. Vagular did not have the opportunity to go to school due to poverty. Vagular and her family live and work on the Rihab Road in Paynesville near Monrovia, Liberia. Her business is the sale of bags of charcoal. She buys her charcoal from rural Liberia and sells retail in the Red Light market in Paynesville. Vagular started by selling plates of cooked food to residents of her community but, because the cooking made her sick -- she developed typhoid fever -- she decided to get into charcoal sales. She has been running her charcoal business for eighteen years and hopes to improve it in the near future. Vagular talks to her customers with a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. She needs this loan to purchase more charcoal to improve her business. Vagular dreams of educating her children and building a house for her family. In the photo, Vagular is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women. Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today!

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 4 years of age, single mother of five children aged between 8 and 23 years all her children go to school.She resides and rents a one roomed house where she stays with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water at home.The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include rent for her residence, medication, school fees and feeding the family. Jane owns a stall selling bananas and tomatoes and also a restaurant in Mengo Mackay. She has done this business for over ten yearsHer main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season because she works from an open place.  She sells both on retail and wholesale. She has been with MCDT for four years servicing her seventh loan working all this long with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas and boxes of tomatoes. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and start a selling on wholesale only
.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas  and boxes of tomatoes to sell

loans.name: United Kerosene Dealers Group

texts.en: Moses F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Kerosene Dealers. He is 35 years old and is married with two children, 4 and 8 years old. He also cares for a sibling. Moses and his family live in the Red Light community and he sells in the Red Light market, the largest market in Liberia, which is located in Paynesville near Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. Moses is a freshman university student studying business. His business is the sale of kerosene which he buys by the barrel and sells per gallon in the Red Light market from a table. He has been running this business for five years and hopes to own a petroleum station in the near future. Moses sells a good product in order to attract more customers to buy from him but sometime faces difficulty in getting kerosene from importers due to shortages in the market. Moses needs this loan to purchase additional kerosene to sell. He dreams of being successful enough to improve his family's living conditions. In the photo, Moses is the one holding the sign. Ayerics K. is inset at lower right. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women. Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today!

loans.use: To purchase additional kerosene to sell

loans.name: Francisca Blanca Rosa

texts.es:
Francisca M. M. de 53 años de edad vive en casa propia junto con sus hijos y su esposo en P.J. Botijeria Angulo Sur – Cercado de Ica su negocio queda ubicado en su mismo domicilio.
La sra se dedica a la venta de chanfaina patasca y otros desde hace mas de 10 años por motivo del terremoto ella fue operada y dejo de lado un poco su negocio que actualmente mantiene ella es apoyada por su esposo ya que dos de sus hijos son profesionales y estan en plenas practicas.
La Sra. siempre a ayudado a sus hijos les ha costeado sus estudios ya que desea que se superen cada día más.
Los esposos son bien trabajadores desean el financiamiento para poder invertir un poco mas en el negocio como es la compra de gaseosas por la Temporada de verano ya que en este tiempo estos productos tienen bastante salida y de esa manera ella obtendría una mejor ganancia que le permitirá seguir apoyando a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Francisca M. M. is 53 years old and lives with her children and her husband in her own home in the new settlement Botijeria Angulo Sur, located in the Cercado de Ica area. She runs her business out of this same home. For over 10 years, she has worked selling traditional South American soups such as chainfaina and patasca. When the earthquake hit, she had to have an operation, and was obliged to put her business aside for a moment, but today she once again maintains it. Her husband helps her with the business, since her 2 sons are professionals who are too busy to help with her business. Señora Franisca has always helped her children, paying for all their education, always hoping to see them achieve more every day. Señora Francisca and her husband are good workers. They hope for a loan so that they will be able to invest a little more in their business, purchasing sodas to sell in the summer, since they are very popular items during that time of year. By doing this, Señora Francisca would earn more income from her business, permitting her to continue helping her children to strive for success.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: INVERSION EN SU NEGOCIO

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more new clothing to sell

loans.name: Luz Marleni

texts.es:
La sra H. D. G. D. 46 años D. edad vive con sus hijos quienes trabajan independientemente y aportan en la unidad familiar todos viven en Los Florales – Acomayo – Parcona – Ica en casa propia.
La sra se dedica a la venta D. verduras enteras y picadas listas para la preparacion D. comidas tambien venD. fruta en esta temporada ella se dedica a este negocio desD. hace 20 años y gracias a este trabajo a logrado obtener su casa darles educacion a su hijos ya que ella esta separada D. su esposo desD. hace mas D. 12 años y ella ha sido madre y padre para ellos.
En su trabajo es bien dedicada emprendedora y da muy buena atención a sus clientes por lo que son fieles a ella antes vendia en calle maurtua pero cuando fue la inundacion en 1997 ella se traslado a la Calle Huancavelica donD. actualmente ofrece sus productos.
Solicita un financiamiento para poder invertir más en su negocio ya que estamos en temporad D. uva y mango.
Ella trabaja desD. las 6.30 a.m. hasta las 2:00 p.m. y en la tarD. venD. chanfaina en su casa por eso tiene buena acumulacion D. bienes.
texts.en:
H. D. G., 46, lives with her children. They work independently and contribute to the family. All of them live in their own house in Los Florales – Acomayo – Parcona – Ica. She sells whole vegetables that are chopped and ready for food preparation. She also sells fruit this season. She has been in this business for 20 years. Thanks to this work she has been able to get a house and give her children an education. She has been separated from her husband for over 12 years, and she has been mother and father to her children. In her work she is a very devoted entrepreneur. She gives her customers very good attention, and that is why they are loyal to her. Previously, she sold on Maurtua Street. There was a flood in 1997, and that is when she moved the Huancavelica Street. That is where she currently offers her products. She is asking for a loan to be able to invest more in her business because we are in the grape and mango season. She works from 6:30 a.m. until 2:00 p.m. In the afternoon she sells “chanfaina” (a type of stew traditionally maD. from the less-noble parts of the animal - offal). That is why she has a good amount of assets.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam C. is married and a small business person. She has been in the business for three years. Mariam runs a business selling both used and new clothes at Tungi Awr in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her goods from Karume, small business city market center for used goods and from the Kariakoo wholesale shopping center. Business income generated from the business is used to meet her daily family needs and to expand the business. 

Mariam is requesting a loan of T.shs. 500,000 to buy more business goods. .

loans.use: To buy more new and used clothing for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of rice

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina is a 31 year old single mother. Her one child, aged 17 years, attends school. Madina resides in and rents a two roomed house where she is staying with  two other people. The family has access to electricity and piped water at home. Her family has three meals a day. Madina monthly expenses include medication, feeding the family, and school fees for her only child. Madina is a hair dresser in Bwaise where she owns a ladies salon. 

Her main challenge is the rainy season because she works from an open place.  She also sells products, both on retail and wholesale. She has been with MCDT for four years and is making her seventh loan working with the same loan group. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of conditioning cream and hair relaxers. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start a bridal salon.
.

loans.use: To buy more conditiong creams and hair relaxers

loans.name: Mussi

texts.en:
Mussi H. is married and a small business woman. She runs a business of keeping poultry, at Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam region. She keeps egg layers at her three poultry cages with 1,000 hen. Poultry chicks are purchased direct from the Inter-Chick company and sometimes from other chick agency and suppliers.

Mussi has been in the business for two years and the income generated from selling eggs and other poultry products has helped her to expand the business by constructing more poultry cages. She needs a loan of T.shs 400,000 to buy more poultry chicks .

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Heradio Adrian

texts.es: Heradio Adrian tiene 61 años, su actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 9 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que actualmente cuenta con muchos clientes, a pesar de la difícil situación es un hombre que sabe, administrar su negocio y poco a poco fue mejorando pues tenía a sus 4 hijos a su cargo, esto lo motiva a seguir adelante, porque sus hijos necesitan estudios, medicamentos y otras cosas básicas. El financiamiento que este hombre luchador necesita es para la compra de golosinas, refrescos naturales, pan, leche, detergente entre otras cosas. El sueño de Heradio es obtener las suficientes ganancias para mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Heradio Adrian is 61 years old, and his main economic activity is a grocery store. He has had this store for more than 9 years, and currently has many customers. In spite of a difficult situation, he is a man who knows how to run his business, and little by little he has been improving it. Since he had 4 children in his care, this motivated him to continue to push ahead, because his children need education, medicine, and other basic things. The loan that this hardworking man needs is to buy candy, fruit drinks, bread, milk, detergent, and other items. Heradio's dream is to have sufficient income to improve the living conditions of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital to buy grocery items

loans.name: Mactar

texts.fr: Monsieur Matar N. est un jeune ouakamois de 29 ans sociétaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC depuis 5 ans. Il est célibataire sans enfants  mais doit subvenir a ses charges personnelles. Depuis 6 ans il s’adonne a l’aviculture. C’est un moyen pour lui de ne pas tomber dans le piège du chômage. Pour lui l’étape la plus passionnante dans son activité c’est la période des 10 premiers jours marquée par leur évolution. Monsieur N. sollicite un crédit de 150 000 frs pour l’achat de poussins afin d’augmenter le nombre de ses sujets. Il est orphelin de mère, son père étant retraite ses revenus lui permettent de soutenir ses membres de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Matar N. is a young, 29 year old, resident of Ouakam and a member of the U-IMCEC credit union for the last 5 years. He is single with no children, but must meet personal expenses. For the past 6 years, he has been raising poultry. It is a way for him to avoid falling into the trap of unemployment. For him, the most exciting stage is their 10 first days of development. Mr N. requesting a loan of 150 000 francs for the purchase of chicks to increase his flock. Since he lost his mother, and his father is retired, his income allows him to support his family members.

Translated from French by Caroline Mrejen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing chicks

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase additional drugs such as ampicillin, septrin, and paracetamol for resale.

loans.name: Adamah

texts.en: Ms. F. works selling fabrics in the Grand Marché of Lomé, Togo. This high-traffic area keeps her busy with her work. She has been in this business since 1988 and is now asking for her first loan from WAGES. She plans on using this loan to resupply her stock of fabrics used for women’s clothing. Ms. F. was born in Aneho, a town east of Lomé, close to the Benin border. She is single and has no children.

loans.use: Fabric for clothing

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha A. M. is an entrepreneur who is married with two school-aged children. She runs a business selling clothes at the MjiMwema ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the business goods from wholesalers and retailers at the Kariakoo shops. She sells both used and new clothes to retail businesses and to final consumers. She has been in the business for four years and the income helps her to expand the business and meet her family's daily demands.  

She needs a loan of 400,000 Tanzanian shillings to boost up the business.

.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Napoleon

texts.es: Napoleón tiene 44 años de edad, por lo que él se dedica a ofrecer sus servicios musicales. Hace más de 10 años que se dedica a este humilde negocio, el un hombre muy trabajador. Con los ingresos que obtiene los utiliza para sus 2 hijos que son lo más importantes para él, por lo que él está muy interesado en proporcionarles a sus hijos estudios y en la manutención de su hogar, el disfruta de su trabajo pues desde muy niño le gusto tocar piano, y fue más tarde que decide ofrecer sus servicios en diferentes lugares. Es por eso que solicita este financiamiento para realizar la compra de accesorios musicales. Su deseo es lograr que su grupo toque a nivel internacional y sean muy reconocidos.
texts.en:
Napoleón is 44 years old and offers musical services. For 10 years he has been dedicated to this humbling business and is a hard working man. He uses the income he earns for his 2 children who are most important to him. For this he is very interested in giving them an education and maintaining his house. He enjoys his job. Since he was a young child he liked playing the piano and it was later that he decided to offer his services in different places. It is for this that he is soliciting a loan to buy music accesories. His wish is that his group with play at an international level and be well recognized.

Translated from Spanish by karl baumgarten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: work capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more peanuts, oil, flour, etc., for resale

loans.name: Maria Victoria

texts.es: Maria Victoria tiene 43 años, su actividad económica es la venta de cosméticos. Ella inicio esta actividad desde hace 6 años, ya que fue una alternativa de ingresos que le ayudara con sus 2 hijos, ya que ambos dependen de Maria, cuando inicio no tenía mucha experiencia con este negocio, por lo que varios clientes no le pagaron y ella tuvo que pagar por esos productos, pero fue una experiencia que obtuvo, por lo que actualmente solo brinda sus productos al contado, esto no la detuvo para salir adelante con su pequeño negocio es una persona muy persistente y convincente motivo por el cual termina rápidamente con sus productos. Ella quiere salir adelante es por eso que solicita este financiamiento para la compra de perfumes, cremas, colonias, mascarillas, lápiz labiales y pinturas de uñas. Su deseo es tener su propia tienda.
texts.en:
Maria Victoria is 43 years old and sells cosmetics. She started her business 6 years ago to provide additional income to help her 2 children who are both dependent on her. When she started, she didn't have much experience in the business and many customers didn't pay her, so she had to pay for some products out of her own pocket. After this experience, she learned to offer her products only for immediate cash payment. She has pushed forward with her small business as she is a very persistent person so she sells out of her products quickly. She is seeking a loan to help her purchase perfumes, creams, colognes, mascara, lip liners, and nail polish. She would like to sometime own her own store.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: By God's Grace Group

texts.en:
Emma K., third from right, is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. They are residents of Makeni city, northern Sierra Leone where they own small-scale businesses. They have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each from SMT/Kiva lenders to enable them to expand their businesses.

The 33-year-old group leader is married to a businessman and they have 3 children. One of their children is in Junior Secondary School III (JSS III), the other in JSS I and the youngest is in class I. Emma has been selling rice and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) for 4 years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy bags of rice and gallons of palm oil.

(Beneath in the photo is Haja C. who was not present for the group snapshot.)

loans.use: Buy bags of rice and gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Lorgia Maria

texts.es: La señora Lorgia tiene negocio de venta de artesanías en Managua, el crédito lo utilizara para la compra de útiles escolares de sus hijos ya que las clases empezaran en la primera semana de febrero el crédito le beneficia a su familia ya que así los niños van a poder ir a clases doña Lorgia es madre de cinco niños pero solamente tres estudian, desde muy temprano se prepara para ir a su cumplir su día de trabajo ya que se tiene que trasladar a la capital regresando a horas altas de la noche esto lo hace con el fin de darle una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos a los que ella ama mucho.
texts.en:
Lorgia has a business selling handicrafts in Managua. She will use the loan to buy school supplies for her children. Classes will start the first week in February. The loan will benefit her family because this way her children will be able to go to school. Lorgia has five children, but only three go to school. She starts to prepare for her work day very early because she has to go to the capital. She returns late at night. She does it in order to give her children, whom she loves a great deal, a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy uniforms and school supplies for her children

loans.name: Yuliana Milagros

texts.es: La Sra Yuliana Milagros H. L. de 30 años de edad, es madre soltera tiene 1 hijo menor. Ella se encuentra domiciliada en la casa de sus padres ubicada en el Caserio de Sacta. Trabaja como obrera de campo en una empresa agroindustrial desde hace 2 años. Gracias a su empeño, esfuerzo esta sacando adelante a su hijo, esta logrando adquirir sus bienes. Requiere el crédito para mejoramiento de vivienda ya que en el terremoto del 2007 la casa de sus padres se vio efectada. Su sueño es construir la vivienda para lograr una mejor calidad de vida. Esta muy agradecida por el apoyo que le podamos brindar a través de este financiamiento.
texts.en:
Yuliana Milagros H. L. is 30 years old and a single mother of one young boy. She lives in her parents' home in Caserio de Sacta. She has worked in the fields of an agricultural business for the past 2 years. Thanks to her hard work and efforts, she is able to support her son and provide for his needs. She is requesting the loan to improve her home which was damaged in the earthquake of 2007. Her dream is to rebuild the house to improve her standard of living. She is very grateful for the support she will receive through this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home improvement

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia I. is an entrepreneur and a married Tanzanian woman. She runs a business selling traditional clothes (Batick and Khanga) at the Karume city market shopping center. She purchases the business goods from the Mnazi mmoja traditional clothes shopping center. She has been in the business for five years. 

The business income enables her to meet her family's daily demand and capitalize the business. She needs a loan of 1,400,000 Tanzanian shillings to expand the business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Cándida Rosa

texts.es: Doña Cándida H. tiene el negocio situado en su casa de habitación situada en Catarina lo que ella vende carne de res ella compra el animal en pies y luego paga para que se lo destacen, el crédito lo utilizara para la compra de una res esto con el fin de aumentar sus ventas y poder tener una mayor ganancia y a si darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida, ella ha tenido tres crédito con CEPRODEL donde le ha beneficiado ya que también ha mejorado su vivienda Doña Cándida es casada, tienen tres hijos de los cuales estudian dos.
texts.en:
Cándida H. has her business in her house in Catarina. She sells beef. She buys the animals, and then pays to have them butchered.
